 baby length: 0.01 in.
 baby weight: 1.134 grams.

The ball of cells now resembles a tadpole and is as big as a peppercorn. The creation of the brain, spinal cord, heart, and blood vessels is already well under way.\n Baby Length: 0.05in. \n Baby Weight: 1.14 gm.

Your little one has tripled in size and is protected by amniotic fluid. Although he is grown by leaps and bounds, he is still only about the size of a pomegranate seed.\n Baby Length: 0.13in.\n Baby Weight: 1.25 gm.
Your baby is now about the size of a small blueberry. Her arm buds, which formed last week, now look like paddles.\n Baby Length: 0.50in.\n Baby Weight: 1.35 gm.

Your baby is now about the size of the fruit of the berries. The hands and feet are having fingers now. Soon this excess fabric will be absorbed to the fingers Child length: 0.63 in.\n Baby weight: 1.66 grams

Your baby has graduated from embryo to fetus , and is now about the size of a cherry. The digestive tract and reproductive organs are formed, but it is still too early for even a skilled technician to tell whether you are having a boy or a girl.\n Baby Length: 0.09in.\n Baby Weight: 1.98 gm.
Your baby is about the size of a kumquat and can stretch his spine. Her eyes and eyelids are more developed and her eyebrows are beginning to grow.\n Baby Length: 1.22in.\n Baby Weight: 4 gm.
Your baby is about the size of a fig. From now through week 20 of your pregnancy, he will increase 30_fold in weight and triple in length.\n Baby Length: 1.61in.\n Baby Weight: 7.

Your baby is almost three inches long now, about the size of a lime. Fingernails, toenails, and bones are forming, and a fine layer of hair covers most of her body.\n Baby Length: 2.13in.\n Baby Weight: 13.89 gm.
Your beautiful baby is the size of a Meyer lemon this week_and his vocal cords are beginning to develop.\n Baby Length: 2.91in.\n Baby Weight: 23 gm.

As you enter your second trimester, your baby is the size of a peach. All of her internal organs formed during the first trimester, and they will continue to mature from now until she is born.\n Baby Length: 3.42in.\n Baby Weight: 43 gm.

Your baby is now the size of an apple. His brain now controls all the muscles in her body , he is able to move. Yes, he will even do somersaults! But if this is your first baby, you probably will not feel him moving for several more weeks.\n Baby Length: 3.98in.\n Baby Weight: 70 gm.
Your baby is now the size of an avocado ,and she can make a fist and even suck her thumb.\n Baby Length: 4.57in.\n Baby Weight: 100 gm.
Your baby is now the size of a pear. He has hiccupped before, but this is the first time you might feel it.\n Baby Length: 5.12in.\n Baby Weight: 140 gm.
Your baby is now about the size of a small artichok , and her tiny fingers now have unique fingerprints!\n Baby Length: 5.59in.\n Baby Weight: 190 gm.

Your baby is now about the size of a mango. His legs are now longer than his arms, and he will start giving you _hello_ jabs at regular intervals, which you may be able to feel if this is your second or third pregnancy. First_time moms still might not feel anything for a few more weeks.\n Baby Length: 6.02in.\n Baby Weight: 240 gm.
Your baby is now the size of a banana. She may have thin eyebrows and is sprouting some hair on her head.\n Baby Length: 6.46in.\n Baby Weight: 300 gm.
Your baby is as long as a carrot, and his skin now responds to touch. If you put pressure on your belly, he will move away or push back.\n Baby Length: 10.51in.\n Baby Weight: 360 gm.

Your baby is the size of a papaya. Her lungs are developing rapidly, and they will begin making a protein called surfactant, which will help her breathe independently once she is born.\n Baby Length: 10.94in.\n Baby Weight: 430 gm.
Your baby is as big as a sweet potato. His brain and hearing are more developed this week, and he is beginning to recognize your voice.\n Baby Length: 11.38in.\n Baby Weight: 1.10lb.

Your baby is as long as an ear of corn. Her nostrils are opening now for _practice breathing_. she will go through the same motions of real breathing but inhale amniotic fluid instead of air.\n Baby Length: 11.81in.\n Baby Weight: 1.32lb.
Your baby is the size of an acorn squash. He is developing a firm grasp and may reach out and grab the umbilical cord. He can also stick out his tongue!\n Baby Length: 13.62in.\n Baby Weight: 1.46lb.
Your baby is nearly as long as a zucchini. Her eyebrows and eyelashes are well_defined; plus, she has more hair on her head this week.\n Baby Length: 14.02in.\n Baby Weight: 1.68lb.
Your baby is now the size of a cauliflower. At this point, he may be able to distinguish between your voice and your husband or partner voice.\n Baby Length: 14.41in.\n Baby Weight: 1.93lb.
Your baby is the size of an eggplant, and she is beginning to open her eyes and blink.\n Baby Length: 14.80in.\n Baby Weight: 2.22lb.
Your baby is the size of a large butternut squash. His skin is still wrinkly, but as fat accumulates, he will fill out.\n Baby Length: 15.20in.\n Baby Weight: 2.54lb.

Your baby is the size of a large cabbage. She has cycles of sleeping and waking. After 30 to 90 minutes of snoozing, she may give you a kick to let you know she is awake.\n Baby Length: 15.71in.\n Baby Weight: 2.91lb.
Your baby is about the size of a coconut, and she will now gain as much as a half pound per week until she is born.\n Baby Length: 16.18in.\n Baby Weight: 3.31lb.

Your baby is the size of a Napa cabbage. Because her taste buds are developed, she may acquire a preference for the foods you eat, which she samples when she swallows amniotic fluid.\n Baby Length: 16.69in.\n Baby Weight: 3.75lb.

Your baby is the size of a pineapple. Lanugo, the fine hair that covered her entire body and helped keep her warm as she developed, is starting to disappear, but there might still be patches of it on her shoulders and back.\n Baby Length: 17.20in.\n Baby Weight: 4.23lb.

Your baby is the size of a cantaloupe. Her bones are fully developed by now, and she is turning her head, pirouetting, and moving her body from side to side.\n Baby Length: 17.72in.\n Baby Weight: 4.73lb.
Your baby is the size of a honeydew melon. In preparation forbirth, he is now upside down in your uterus.\n Baby Length: 18.19in.\n Baby Weight: 5.25lb.
Your baby is about the size of a head of romaine lettuce, and her wrinkly suit of skin is filling out as she gets plumper.\n Baby Length: 18.66in.\n Baby Weight: 5.75lb.

Your baby is as long as stalk of Swiss chard. Because he is running out of room in your uterus, he mostly stretches and wiggles, instead of delivering big kicks.\n Baby Length: 19.13in.\n Baby Weight: 6.30lb.
Your baby is the length of a leek. Connections are forming in her brain that will help her swallow and even sleep better once she is born.\n Baby Length: 19.61in.\n Baby Weight: 6.80lb.

Your baby now weighs as much as a pumpkin. At this point, he has shed most of that white creamy substance called vernix and the fine, fur_like hair called lanugo that has covered his skin since the middle of your second trimester.\n Baby Length: 19.96in.\n Baby Weight: 7.25lb.

By the time she is born, your baby may be watermelon size. You are expecting to give birth this week, but do not worry if your baby decides to stick around a little longer. Many first babies are late, and she will be worth the wait_we promise!\n Baby Length: 20.16in.\n Baby Weight: 7.63lb.

string-array.name: baby_develop_eng
string-array.item: Baby? What baby? This concept may be a little hard to wrap your head around, but even though you are technically in the first week of pregnancy, you are not quite expecting yet. \n Here is the deal: Because it is generally impossible to know the exact moment of conception, most healthcare providers count 40 weeks from the first day of your last menstrual period (LMP) to calculate your due date. According to this method, they date the beginning of pregnancy from about two weeks before the sperm penetrates the egg which is where you are right now. \n Already spotted that pink line on a home pregnancy test? You are further along than you think, so skip ahead to Week 4.

So far your baby does not exist, but this is the week you ovulate. Your ovary releases a ripened egg (ovum) into your fallopian tube, where it will patiently await the sperm that have survived the 6 to 8 inch trek through your cervix and uterus. While 75 to 900 million sperm embark on this journey, less than a thousand actually make it past your cervix , and only one lucky swimmer will have the honor of penetrating the egg at the moment of conception.

Amazingly, your child sex and all of her inherited genetic characteristics _ such as eye color, hair color, skin, and body type , have been set since the moment of conception.\n Your developing baby, now called a zygote, has 46 chromosomes , 23 from you and 23 from your partner. These chromosomes help determine your baby sex and traits such as eye and hair color, and, to some extent, personality and intelligence. \n After fertilization, the ball of cells, now an embryo, will wrap up its journey through the fallopian tube and burrow itself into the wall of your uterus for nourishment , a process known as implantation. If you are having multiples, the deed has already been done. Fraternal twins occur when two separate eggs are fertilized by two different sperm and each baby has his own placenta and amniotic sac. If one fertilized egg splits and develops into two fetuses, the result is identical twins. They may share a placenta, but each baby usually has a separate amniotic sac.

Your fetus may be small now, but be aware that very important developments are already under way. \n This week the fetus is divided into two parts. Half of the placenta will become the special tissue that provides nutrients and oxygen to your baby throughout the entire pregnancy. In the other half, the embryo itself is still growing, the paper has just begun to create a neural tube, where your baby brain, spinal cord and spine will eventually form.

This week, your baby ticker will start beating for the first time! (Neither you nor your doctor can hear it yet, but it may be possible to see the movement on an ultrasound.) And your little one has been really busy growing! The embryo now has three distinct layers: the outer ectoderm, which will form the nervous system, ears, eyes, inner ear and many connective tissues; the endoderm, or inner layer, which will grow into internal organs like the lungs, intestines and bladder; and the middle mesoderm, which will eventually make way for the heart and circulatory system. \n In the weeks to come, the mesoderm will also evolve into bones, muscles, kidneys and reproductive organs.

By the end of this week your baby will have tripled in size! \n His heart is now beating with a regular rhythm. It is still too faint to be picked up by your doctor stethoscope, but if you have an ultrasound at some point over the next few weeks it will probably be visible as a tiny, pulsing dot in the middle of his mini body. \n Fun fact: From now until birth, your child heart will beat about 150 times a minute _ twice the average adult rate. Also this week, your baby brain hemispheres are forming _ and brain waves can now be recorded.

Your baby is already developing amazingly distinct facial features. Dark spots mark the areas where her eyes and nostrils will be, and a little mouth and ears are starting to form, too. Your baby brain is also growing more complex; if you could take a peek, it would be clearly visible inside the transparent skull. In fact, nerve cells in your baby brain are growing at an amazing rate _ 100,000 cells per minute! And she has started to move in small, jerky motions, although you will not feel these movements until about your fourth month of pregnancy.

Your baby growth boom continues: in the past two weeks has quadrupled. As it becomes larger, the features of his face become more refined, with his ears, upper lip, and tip of his small nose all visible. His eyelid will also be forming for the first time this week, and his heart is getting stronger day by day.

Even though you still have to wait another eight weeks to find out if your new addition will be a boy or a girl, this week, your baby gets the goods she will need to, well, make her own baby one day. That is right _ reproductive organs are beginning to form now, along with some other key organs, like the pancreas and gallbladder. At this point your baby has doubled in size and her head, which is about half the length of her entire body, is tucked down toward her chest. Her tiny fingers are growing longer, and the ends are slightly enlarged right now _ this is where those unique fingerprints will ultimately form.

Up until now your baby was classified as an embryo, but by the end of this week he will be a fetus and lots of changes are on the way. Paddle_like, or webbed, hands and feet will now separate into fingers and toes, bones will begin to harden and his kidneys are now producing urine. Most impressive? At this point your baby brain is developing at astounding rates _ nearly 250,000 neurons are forming every minute! The end of the embryonic stage also marks a turning point for development dangers _ your baby is much less susceptible to them now.

Did you know your baby can breathe underwater? She doing it right now. At weeks 10 and 11, the fetus will start to inhale and exhale small amounts of amniotic fluid, which helps your baby lungs to grow and develop. Also this week, your baby ears are scooting up to the sides of his head. Sure, your baby head is still disproportionally large compared to the rest of his body, but this will even out as he continues to grow and develop in the womb.

As your baby muscles start to bulk up at this stage, he is getting busy stretching and kicking. When you put your hand on your belly, your baby will likely wiggle in response because his reflexes are starting to develop _ though it is too early to feel his movements. He will also start to open and close his fingers, curl his toes, and jerk and kick his arms and legs.

Your baby is constantly getting bigger and cuter, and his face is looking more human_like every day. His ears have moved up from his neck into place and his eyes _ which are looking more and more like your baby blues (or browns, or greens) _ have moved from the sides of the head to the front of the face. Up until now, his head has been outpacing his body, but now his body is growing faster. His legs still need to grow longer, but this week his arms will lengthen to be proportionate with his body, and he will be able to stick his thumb in his mouth. Also by now, all of your baby essential organs and systems have formed.

The roof of your baby tiny mouth is fully formed now, and her constant sucking reflexes are helping to create full, cherubic cheeks. If you are having a boy, the prostate is forming, and if you are having a girl, her ovaries are moving down into her pelvis.

Lanugo, your baby first ultrafine, downy hair, now covers his back, shoulders, ears, and forehead. It helps him retain body heat, but once he gains enough fat to do the job, this hair will fall off _ probably before birth. Facial expressions are your baby newest trick _ he can frown, squint, grimace and wince. Do not worry _ he is just flexing his facial muscles, not indicating his mood.

Your baby delicate skeleton continues to harden from rubbery cartilage to bone. Even so, his bones will remain somewhat flexible for an easier trip through the birth canal. The umbilical cord has fully matured with one vein and two arteries that are protected by Wharton jelly (a thick substance that makes the cord slippery so it can move freely around your baby). By the way, if you are having a girl, hundreds of thousands of eggs are forming in her ovaries this week _ your future grandchildren!

Finally, your baby arms, legs, and trunk have caught up to the size of his head. Baby starts plumping up this week, as body fat is deposited under his skin and sweat glands develop. Also worth noting: The placenta is almost as big as your baby. It provides vitamins, minerals, proteins, fats, and oxygen, along with removing waste and filtering carbon dioxide.

Do you and your partner talk to your baby? Well, with the bones and nerves in her ears now developed enough to function, she can hear all sorts of sounds _ including blood coursing through the umbilical cord, your growling tummy, and your heartbeat. In fact, sudden or loud noises may startle her. Go ahead and sing, tell stories or play music for your baby now. Even though your baby does not understand what these sounds are now, eventually she will recognize your voice better than any other.

Vernix caseosa begins to coat the skin. The greasy, cheese_like white coating helps regulate body temperature and protects your baby skin while it is submerged in amniotic fluid. By the time your baby is born, most of the vernix will be gone. Your baby heartbeat is growing stronger now and it is about twice as fast as yours.

Your baby is as happy as a clam in your womb, as his well_developed limbs continue to explore by curling, flexing, and kicking. And as his hair, nails and eyebrows continue to sprout, your fetus is looking remarkably more and more like Mom and Dad every day.

Part of your baby growth spurt at this point is likely because his stomach is now equipped to start absorbing energy_boosting nutrients from the amniotic fluid he is swallowing in there. Most of your baby nourishment is still coming directly from the placenta, though.

Your baby previously see_through skin will now become opaque. However, it will remain wrinkly, red, and covered in vernix until more fat helps to fill it out. Also this week, he is fine-tuning his sense of touch (thanks to maturing brain cells and nerve endings). Your baby may experiment with these newfound skills by feeling his face or anything else he can get his hands on. This week, your baby eyebrows start growing and hair will start sprouting on the scalp, but this varies _ your baby may grow a thick head of dark hair or he may enter the world bald.

Billions of brain cells will develop in your baby brain over the next couple of weeks. These will control all of your baby movements and sensory, and basic life functions like breathing. Also around this time, some major changes are happening with your baby lungs. Surfactant is being produced, a substance that enables the air sacs to inflate and the lungs to fully expand. Right now he is still breathing amniotic fluid, but when he is born he will be ready for air.

You might notice that your baby is very busy during the next few weeks. Right now she is small enough to have plenty of room to move and groove in your belly. She may even respond to your soothing voice or the rubbing of your belly by calming down, while loud sounds or a tap on your belly could cause her to become alert. Also, because the balance_controlling inner ear has developed, your baby can finally tell if she is upside down or right side up, so moving around takes on new meaning.

Your baby first bowel movement has been forming in the large intestine. The thick, dark poop is called meconium and it is typically excreted shortly after he is born. Occasionally babies pass this stool before they are born, which means it must be suctioned after birth to clear it from the lungs.

Your baby has settled into a distinct sleep_wake pattern. You may notice that sometimes he is very active and kicking or punching, and other times he sleeps. If you are lucky, these patterns will mimic yours.

Your baby has been hiccuping every once in a while for several weeks, and now you might actually feel these baby hiccups, which are triggered by the involuntary movements of his diaphragm. (In adults, this is followed by the quick closure of our vocal cords, which is what makes that familiar "hic" sound.) But because your baby trachea is filled with fluid instead of air, his fetal hiccups do not make a sound. They will make your belly jump though, which is fun to see and feel!

Until now, your baby eyelids have been fused shut, but this week he will begin to open and close his eyes. What is more, his irises are now filled with pigment. Even if you could peek at the color of his peepers now, though, they might not stay that color, as a baby eyes can change up until he is 6 months to 1 year old (especially if your little guy is born with baby blues).

Your baby is getting stronger by the minute. This week, her pushes, kicks, and rolls will likely occur more frequently _ and forcefully. So do not be surprised if you feel an extra_strong karate chop or two! Around this time, the part of your baby brain associated with intelligence and personality becomes far more complex. You can get to know your baby by paying attention to how she reacts to different foods, sounds, and lights.

From this point on your baby will gain about a half pound each week. All that baby weight is for more than filling out his chubby cheeks. Now that all of his major body systems are in place and functioning, he needs padding to protect and insulate his organs. His built_up fat tissue will also help him regulate his body temperature after birthand provide the energy he needs. Because your baby is adding fat and growing bigger, you might find his movements become less frequent _ it is getting harder for him to maneuver. But if you are not feeling any jabs or the occasional kick, tell your health care provider.

Your baby is gaining more weight than height at this point. Because she is too big to stretch out, she is now forced into the fetal position, which she will stay in until birth. This this week also boasts some exciting reproductive developments. Having a boy? His testicles are moving through the groin on their way into the scrotum. And if you have got a girl in there, her clitoris is already relatively formed.

While a teeny part of you might be thinking _Get this kid outta here ASAP!_ we bet the rest is sincerely hoping he will stay in there a while longer. That said, you can breathe a sigh of relief for this week important milestone. Almost all babies born at this stage or later survive and go on to have very healthy, normal lives. By this time all of his major organs are fully functioning except the lungs, which need just a bit more time to mature completely.

Your baby does not have much elbow room these days _ and, happily, that is probably going to mean fewer elbow jabs to the ribs for you. Because space in your uterus is running out, your baby becomes less active at this point in the pregnancy. You may also notice that her movements are affected by your daily routine _ how much and when you eat, what position you are in and sounds from the world outside can all affect your baby activity level.

Your baby is preparing for his arrival in just a few short weeks! This week, the protective vernix caseosa (that cheese_like, white, waxy coating that is keeping his skin safe) begins to thicken, ensuring that his birthday suit stays smooth and well_moisturized during D_day. Your baby will likely arrive covered in the stuff, especially in the folds under his arms, behind his ears, and in the groin area. But it will all be washed off very shortly after birth , during his first_ever bath.

At this point, your unborn baby should be positioned with her head facing down toward the cervix and vagina. About 97 percent of babies have adopted this position by this point; the rest remain in what is known as breech position , when the butt or feet are in place to come out first. If your baby is among this minority, it does increase your odds of needing a C_section, but there is a good chance your healthcare provider can correct the problem by turning him around manually with pressure applied on your belly. Called an external version, this process has about a 65 percent success rate.

Your baby is working hard to accumulate all the fat he can at this point, and that layer of fat has now rounded out his face. This build_up of fat , about 15 percent of his total weight , will help him maintain his body temperature and give him a store of energy. His sucking muscles, which are quite powerful, have also finished developing now, and are ready for their first real feeding , your baby is going to be hungry soon after he arrives.

The umbilical cord begins passing antibodies to your baby in preparation for delivery. By stockpiling antibodies, your baby will be better prepared for the disease and germs he will encounter outside the womb. Your baby senses are also getting more time to hone their burgeoning skills. He can hear and recognize your voice. Once he is born you will be able to see him turn his head in your direction when he hears you speak. He knows his mom! Along with his hearing, his eyesight is improving each day. His fingers are also becoming more coordinated. He can grasp his face or toes. And after birth he will be able to grab onto your finger.

Your baby is hanging out, enjoying her last few weeks of snuggly comfort in your womb. However, if she were born today, she would still be considered a full_term infant. Her brain _ in charge of complicated jobs like regulating breathing, digestion, and circulation _ is functioning better every day. Babies come to term anywhere between 38 and 42 weeks; your 40 _week due date simply marks the midpoint of this period.

By now your baby has likely reached his birth weight (typically between 6 and 9 pounds) and length (18 to 22 inches from head to toe). He is accumulated enough body fat to stay cozy after he is born, and your placenta continues to supply him with nutrients and antibodies that will help fend off illnesses. If you could sneak a peek at your baby final moments before birth, you would see that his head is down toward your pelvis (if he is not in the bottom_down or breech presentation, in which case your healthcare provider might suggest a cesarean section). Your baby body will either be straight up and down, called longitudinal, or positioned at an angle, called oblique. Along with spying your baby body position, if you could see his head, you would notice that he is head_down and facing your spine, which is the most common position (called anterior presentation). But sometimes, babies present head_down but facing toward your abdomen. This is called occiput or cephalic posterior. Your baby might lean slightly to one side or the other, meaning that he is either right or left anterior, or right or lef posterior.

When your baby arrives, he will be evaluated and graded (zero to two points each) on the following factors: activity and muscle tone, pulse (heart rate), grimace response (medically known as reflex irritability), appearance (skin coloration) and respiration (breathing rate and effort). This sum will determine the baby Apgar score _ an initial measure of his health. Most healthy babies have an Apgar between seven and nine (few babies get a 10).

string-array.name: baby_sonar_eng
string-array.item: There is no ultrasound image of your baby to be for weeks 1 and 2. While your health care provider counts these two weeks toward your due date, you are not really pregnant. Confused? Your pregnancy due date is calculated using the first day of your last menstrual period (LMP). Obviously you were not pregnant at that time, but it is the best reference your health care provider has for estimating baby is arrival day (until you get an ultrasound, which may provide a more accurate due date).

There is no ultrasound image of your baby to be for weeks 1 and 2. While your health care provider counts these two weeks toward your due date, you are not really pregnant. Confused? Your pregnancy due date is calculated using the first day of your last menstrual period (LMP). Obviously you were not pregnant at that time, but it is the best reference your health care provider has for estimating baby is arrival day (until you get an ultrasound, which may provide a more accurate due date).

This week is when your pregnancy really begins. At some point, the sperm joins with the egg as it makes its way from the ovary through the Fallopian tube and then into the uterus. Fertilization takes place inside the Fallopian tube. Once together, the cells begin to divide rapidly so that next week, a sonographer may be able to capture baby_to_be beginnings during an ultrasound examination.

This small circle in the center of the sonogram may not look the phenomenon, but this small sac is a kind of baby cocoon called a gestational bag. The cells that form this sac will begin to specialize. Some cells will become part of the placenta. Some amniotic sac will be filled with fluids to provide food for your baby. And other cells to form everything from sensitive lashes to muscles and skin. But this is still far away.

The dark area is the fluid filling the gestational sac. Eventually, this fluid will be replaced by a sac containing the amniotic fluid your baby_to_be will live in for the next few months. The white circle within the fluid is called the yolk sac. Before the placenta is fully formed, the yolk sac plays a role in providing all the nutrients your baby_to_be needs to grow. Adjacent to the yolk sac, little + marks show a very early embryo. The sonographer measures the length of the embryo (the crown-rump length or CRL) to confirm or revise the due date estimated from your LMP, or to evaluate the embryo growth.

In this 3D image of the developing embryo, you can see a big change since previous week of the first trimester. The baby_to_be curves inward, with the umbilical cord in the middle. The head appears at the upper right side of the image. Small buds can be seen where the arms and legs will eventually develop.

During this week of the first trimester, you can see baby_to_be is developing in a bubble within the gestational sac. The bubble around the embryo is the amniotic cavity filled with amniotic fluid. This liquid environment gives your baby room to grow and develop and to move. The amniotic fluid also cushions your baby_to_be from any external pressure on the abdomen. The black area inside the head is part of the developing neural tube.

In this image, the embryo is lying on her back with its head to the right of the screen. In this fashionable shape, you can see that the baby head to be larger during this part to accommodate the growing brain. The brain is divided into three main parts: the anterior brain, the middle brain, and the hindbrain. As in the previous week, the back brain may be seen as a dark area at the back of the fetal head.

The embryo appears at the bottom of the image with his head on the left. The arms and legs are not seen from this angle, but the umbilical cord can be seen extending from the baby abdomen on its way to the placenta. The sonographer has marked the embryo crown-rump length (CRL), which will help to confirm or revise the due date estimated from the LMP. Amniotic fluid (the dark area) surrounds the developing baby.

You will notice in this image that your baby_to_be is looking more and more like a newborn. Her arms and legs are visible, and a recognizable profile can be seen. The bright white areas in the profile are facial bones.

Baby_to_be is lying on her back with her head on the left side of the image and her legs pointing up. From this image, you can see that her neck is growing, separating her large head from the rest of her body. Her head still makes up more than 50% of her body size, which is normal. Facial bones are again seen as bright white areas in the profile.

With the baby in profile and the head on the right side, you can see that the facial profile is becoming more and more like what you had expect to see in a newborn. The developing baby has one hand in front of the face as if he is shading his eyes.

In this profile shot, notice that the baby_to_be is lying with her bottom on the left_hand side of the image and her head to the right. (Even though the fetus is referred to as _she_ here, the sonographer may or may not be able to identify the baby gender at this point.) Her legs are clearly visible raised up, knees bent. The line across the middle of the profile is the sonographer measurement of baby crown-rump length (CRL). With this measurement, the sonographer is able to determine your baby age.
The sonographer has magnified the image to show the baby_to_be profile. His head is on the right_hand side of the image and his hand is on his chest.

In this 3D image, the baby_to_be is curled up, her hands covering her face (she is about the size of a grapefruit). The large bones that make up her skull are forming and hardening. As they harden, the bones appear whiter and brighter in the image. These cranium pieces do not come together until well after birth.

In this closeup view of Baby profile, you can see how his facial features are becoming more defined. Notice that the sonographer has measured the length of his nasal bone. This specialized measurement may be useful in screening for some genetic abnormalities.

This close_up shows the baby_to_be tiny right hand. You can see each bone within her delicate fingers. Although she may not be coordinated enough now to use her fingers (other than to wiggle!), by the time she is born she will have matured to the point where her fingers will have some dexterity _ she will even be able to grasp your finger with her hand!

Halfway through your pregnancy (18 to 20 weeks) your health care provider may request an ultrasound to evaluate your baby size and anatomy. This image shows a cross sectional view of baby head. The sonographer will measure baby_to_be head circumference or biparietal diameter (BPD).
Your baby legs and arms are continuing to develop and add muscle. You may be able feel your baby movements now, or within the next week or two.

Here, Baby_to_be is curled up with her leg tucked in and her arms covering her face, which is turned away. She may look scrawny now, but developmentally she is right on track. Her bones, visible in this 3D image, are continuing to harden and develop.
This profile image not only shows how your baby_to_be bones and skeletal structures are forming, but also his lungs. Looking at his chest, the sonographer can identify the heart and lung tissue.
Here, the baby_to_be appears to be sleeping (babies in utero do have periods of sleeping and periods of activity).

With the baby_to_be crouched and his legs pulled in toward his chest, you can almost see his complete profile. Images of the baby entire body are difficult now that he is more than 8 inches in length. He is about to experience a dramatic weight gain in the coming weeks. For now, he is still relatively thin.

The image on the left shows a magnified view of the four chambers of the baby_to_be heart. The image on the right show blood flowing from the upper chambers of the heart (the atria) into the lower chambers of the heart (the ventricles). The walls of the ventricles are more muscular than the atria, because they have to pump blood to the baby lungs and the rest of the body.

This close_up image of your baby_to_be ear shows just how developed her features have become. Although her hearing is still rudimentary, by the time she is born she will be able to recognize your voice from hearing it constantly in utero.
Hi, Mom! This image reveals a close_up look at your unborn baby nose and mouth. It is almost as if his face is pressed up against a window.

Now that the baby_to_be is growing rapidly, it is harder to get a complete profile in the womb (she just does not fit in the picture anymore!). Even though she has more than tripled her weight since this trimester began, there is still plenty of growing left to do. This week marks the end of the 2nd trimester , just one more trimester to go.

Welcome to your third (and last) trimester! Your baby_to_be hair is seen waving in the amniotic fluid. This hair is called lanugo. Unfortunately, we can not predict how much hair your baby will have because he will lose his lanugo before being born and it will be replaced with the hair we are used to seeing on infants at birth.

This week, your baby_to_be bones are hardening, and her muscles strengthening. In fact, you may have noticed from her kicks and jabs that she is growing stronger each week. Bones appear bright white on a sonogram. Although you can not see it in this image, your baby has probably been practicing his breathing movements this week, though his lungs still need more time to mature.
This image shows how developed your baby_to_be features have become. With her pouty lips and tiny nose, she looks much like she will at birth. Note the baby hand in front of her eyes and forehead.
This image gives a close_up view of the lower end of your unborn baby spine. You can see the spinal cord protected by the bright white bones of the spine.

There is not much to report on your baby_to_be developmental milestones this week. Much of his growth is strictly adding weight through fat layers that will insulate his maturing organs. He will need plenty of fat tissue to keep him warm once he leaves his home in your womb and enters the world, where the environmental temperature is not as controlled. Although you can not see it in this image, your baby has probably been attempting to breathe this week, though his lungs still need more time to mature. Another development you will notice in this image _ look closely and you might spy the edges of his toenails, which are now fully formed.
Your baby_to_be brain is continuing to grow and develop. In this image, the red and blue show blood flow to the part of his brain that lets the two halves of the brain communicate with one another.
In this image of a profile, the baby mouth is open. She may be drinking amniotic fluid or taking it into her lungs, which aids in the development of her respiratory system.
Your baby is the size of a honeydew melon. In preparation forbirth, he is now upside down in your uterus.\n Baby Length: 18.19in.\n Baby Weight: 5.25lb.

This image of your baby_to_be face looks identical to the profile you will be seeing in person in a few weeks (four or less!). For the remaining weeks, your baby will be adding 0.5 pound each week until birth.

Sometimes your doctor or midwife will ask for a test to check how well your baby is doing. One indicator of your baby_to_be well being is a measurement of the amniotic fluid. This can also be part of a test called a biophysical profile, which will also include watching the baby various movements. In this image, the sonographer is measuring the deepest pocket of fluid in each of four areas of your uterus. As you can see, your baby is getting a bit crowded in there!

During the last few weeks of gestation, your baby has less and less room to move. A few weeks (and pounds) ago, she may have been kicking and wiggling constantly; now she simply does not have enough room. If you or your health care provider have any concerns about your baby development, especially if her movement becomes too infrequent, you may have an ultrasound to check up on her. This image shows the results of monitoring a baby heart rate in utero. At the top, the baby heart beats; below, the lined measurements track and then determine baby heart rate to make sure it is within the normal range.

The sonographer is getting a 0.75 view of your baby_to_be face _ and you can actually see her eyelashes! Your health care provider may want to see if the baby has settled into a head_down position _ the best position for a normal delivery.

If your healthcare provider wants to get an idea of your baby weight, one of the most important measurements the sonographer can take is the abdominal circumference. This image is a cross section of your baby belly. The small back oval is her stomach, and the curved black line is the blood vessel that brings nutrients from the placenta. Soon, you will have a very different way of feeding her!

string-array.name: guide_eng
string-array.item:
Preconception Diet 

 Getting your body ready for baby-making is not only about tossing your birth control and charting your ovulation. It is also about laying the nutritional foundation for healthy baby building. Begin your eating-well campaign even before you conceive (technically these are your first weeks of pregnancy) and you will be doing yourself (and your soon-to-be embryo) a favor. So kiss those fast-food fries good-bye (mostly), ice the ice cream (frozen yogurt makes an almost-as-delicious but far more nutritious substitute), and start eating a pregnancy diet. 
 First item on the to-do list: Become a fool for folic acid (folate). Studies show that the earlier you start getting enough of this vital vitamin - ideally, before you conceive - the lower the chances that your baby will develop neural tube defects (such as spina bifida). Where can you find folic? Most leafy green vegetables and whole grains are naturally full of it - plus, it is added to most refined grain products (by law). Want extra insurance? Taking a prenatal vitamin supplement is an easy way to buy it - and when it comes to folic acid, you can not be too careful (after all, a three salad-a-day habit is a worthy goal - but one you may not always manage to reach). Since you are in this for the long haul, and even after you have overhauled your eating habits, a supplement can be the most realistic way to fit folic acid in day after day after day (especially once you find those days filled with nausea). Choose a prenatal supplement with 400 to 600 mcg of folic acid to be sure you are getting your fill. 
 Second: Junk the junk food. Reduce refined sugars and white flour (in the form of your usual suspects - cookies, doughnuts, Danish, cake, candy, and almost anything else you might grab from the vending machine, the coffee cart, the convenience store racks, the pastry shop display case…you get the picture). Slash saturated fats (sub a side salad for the fries; grilled chicken for the extra crispy) - less is better for your baby, plus a high intake of such fats appears to increase the risk of severe pregnancy nausea and vomiting. (Uh, thanks but no thanks.) 
 Third: Relish the right stuff. Increase all the good things that your body (and your baby-to-be body) needs: green leafies (those delicious salads), yummy yellows (apricots, carrots, papaya, mango), hearty whole grains (whole-wheat bread, brown rice, oatmeal), and low-fat dairy (Got milk? Yogurt? Cheese? You should!). 
 Fourth: Stop being a meal skipper. Are you always more interested in catching the train than breaking for breakfast? Working through lunch instead of eating it? Skip a meal when you are eating for two (which you soon will be) and baby skips it, too. Get into the three-squares habit now so that when baby is on board, he or she will be getting a steady supply of nutrients throughout the day. 
 Finally, take a clear-eyed look at your dietary habits. Might any of them stand in your way of eating well? Do you think you might have an eating disorder that needs pre pregnancy treatment, such as anorexia nervosa or bulimia? Are you on a restricted diet (either self-imposed or due to a chronic condition) that might need to be adapted once you are eating for two, such as macrobiotic, vegan, or diabetic? Now is the time to discuss any of these factors with your practitioner - and to enlist the help of a dietitian if your eating habits need reshaping. Support groups (especially in the case of an eating disorder) can also help you get your nutritional status back where it should be.

Preconception Diet 

 Getting your body ready for baby-making is not only about tossing your birth control and charting your ovulation. It is also about laying the nutritional foundation for healthy baby building. Begin your eating-well campaign even before you conceive (technically these are your first weeks of pregnancy) and you will be doing yourself (and your soon-to-be embryo) a favor. So kiss those fast-food fries good-bye (mostly), ice the ice cream (frozen yogurt makes an almost-as-delicious but far more nutritious substitute), and start eating a pregnancy diet. 
 First item on the to-do list: Become a fool for folic acid (folate). Studies show that the earlier you start getting enough of this vital vitamin - ideally, before you conceive - the lower the chances that your baby will develop neural tube defects (such as spina bifida). Where can you find folic? Most leafy green vegetables and whole grains are naturally full of it - plus, it is added to most refined grain products (by law). Want extra insurance? Taking a prenatal vitamin supplement is an easy way to buy it - and when it comes to folic acid, you can not be too careful (after all, a three salad-a-day habit is a worthy goal - but one you may not always manage to reach). Since you are in this for the long haul, and even after you have overhauled your eating habits, a supplement can be the most realistic way to fit folic acid in day after day after day (especially once you find those days filled with nausea). Choose a prenatal supplement with 400 to 600 mcg of folic acid to be sure you are getting your fill. 
 Second: Junk the junk food. Reduce refined sugars and white flour (in the form of your usual suspects - cookies, doughnuts, Danish, cake, candy, and almost anything else you might grab from the vending machine, the coffee cart, the convenience store racks, the pastry shop display case…you get the picture). Slash saturated fats (sub a side salad for the fries; grilled chicken for the extra crispy) - less is better for your baby, plus a high intake of such fats appears to increase the risk of severe pregnancy nausea and vomiting. (Uh, thanks but no thanks.) 
 Third: Relish the right stuff. Increase all the good things that your body (and your baby-to-be body) needs: green leafies (those delicious salads), yummy yellows (apricots, carrots, papaya, mango), hearty whole grains (whole-wheat bread, brown rice, oatmeal), and low-fat dairy (Got milk? Yogurt? Cheese? You should!). 
 Fourth: Stop being a meal skipper. Are you always more interested in catching the train than breaking for breakfast? Working through lunch instead of eating it? Skip a meal when you are eating for two (which you soon will be) and baby skips it, too. Get into the three-squares habit now so that when baby is on board, he or she will be getting a steady supply of nutrients throughout the day. 
 Finally, take a clear-eyed look at your dietary habits. Might any of them stand in your way of eating well? Do you think you might have an eating disorder that needs pre pregnancy treatment, such as anorexia nervosa or bulimia? Are you on a restricted diet (either self-imposed or due to a chronic condition) that might need to be adapted once you are eating for two, such as macrobiotic, vegan, or diabetic? Now is the time to discuss any of these factors with your practitioner - and to enlist the help of a dietitian if your eating habits need reshaping. Support groups (especially in the case of an eating disorder) can also help you get your nutritional status back where it should be.

Foods to Boost Fertility 
 You might have heard that eating a nutritious prepregnancy diet can prep your body for growing a healthy baby-to-be, but - back up! - did you know that some of those good-for-you foods can help you conceive that baby? Keep clicking to find out which foods boost fertility - and which snacks to skip. 

 Whole Milk 
 Dairy is a definite do when you are trying to conceive - it is chock-full of calcium, which is great for bone and reproductive health. And downing one serving of full-fat dairy a day, like whole milk (or even full-fat ice cream, yum!), can help you overcome ovulation issues and get pregnant. Skip seconds of these full-fat products because they can pack on extra pounds (a fertility no-no), but aim for a total of 1,000 mg of calcium a day by adding snacks of low-fat yogurt or cheese. Lactose-intolerant (or just do not dig dairy)? You can also find fertility-friendly calcium in leafy greens, tofu, and fortified juices. 

 Lean Turkey, Chicken, and Beef 
 Pumping up your iron intake with these lean-protein options is key when you are trying to conceive. Studies show that women with enough iron in their diet tend to be more fertile than ladies who lack it. Add about two servings of these iron-filled foods a day, but do not overdo it on protein - even though it is an essential preconception food, too much protein can actually lower fertility. If you do not eat meat (or just want some variety), munch on plant proteins like beans, tofu, or quinoa instead and be sure your prenatal vitamin contains iron. 

 Whole Grains 
 No need to pass on the bread basket - so long as you opt for a slice of the whole-grain stuff. This source of complex carbohydrates (also found in beans, vegetables, and fruits) contains tons of nutrients, including fertility superstar folic acid (which you may already be loading up on if you are trying to conceive). And while refined carbs (aka white bread, white rice, and sugary snacks) cause your blood sugar to spike - which can mess with your reproductive hormones and menstrual cycle - whole grains keep it stable and may even promote regular ovulation. Carb-counters, rejoice! 

 Salmon 
 Lots of ladies feel fishy about eating seafood when they are trying to conceive, but fatty varieties such as salmon, sardines, and herring are actually fertility-boosting foods. Why? They are full of omega-3 fatty acids, which can help regulate reproductive hormones, increase blood flow to reproductive organs, and even minimize stress. If you have not found your sea legs yet, you can also get your omega-3 fix in flaxseed, walnuts, and enriched eggs, or you can talk to your doctor about supplements. 

 Wild Yams 
 Fact: Twins are common in cultures in which women often fill up on wild yams. Coincidence? Some experts think not - they believe that this starch may help stimulate ovulation. So do not wait until Thanksgiving to serve up this side, especially if you want to expand your family by the next gathering! 

 Berries 
 These fab fruits are full of antioxidants, which are pros at protecting your body cells (read: those precious eggs) from damage and aging. Opt for blueberries and raspberries, which are extra-packed with antioxidants, and pass them on to your partner - studies show that these preconception foods can keep his sperm strong and healthy, too. 

 Oysters 
 This famed aphrodisiac does not just set baby-making in motion - it is also an excellent source of zinc, which is a must when you are trying to conceive (a deficiency of this nutrient can disrupt your cycle and slow egg-production). Can not stomach oysters? Opt for other zinc-filled foods like lean beef and poultry, dairy, whole grains (all of which you should already be eating!), nuts, eggs, and legumes. Pick a prenatal vitamin that contains zinc too. 

 Foods to Avoid 
 Raise your chances of hitting the pregnancy jackpot by steering clear of certain foods, like high-mercury fish. Mercury is linked to infertility, and it can be harmful to a growing baby-to-be, so avoid mercury magnets like swordfish, king mackerel, tilefish, tuna steak, and shark. Trans fats (aka hydrogenated or partially hydrogenated oils) found in processed and fried foods are also conception busters, so nix noshes like packaged snacks and doughnuts and read nutrition labels carefully to search for hidden trans fats. Choose foods with prepregnancy-friendly polyunsaturated fats and monounsaturated fats, found in nuts, vegetable oils, and fatty fish.

Caffeine During Pregnancy — Taming the Habit 


 If you always count on that cup of morning brew (or maybe those five cups to get you through to lunch), you have some thinking to do now that you are 4 weeks pregnant. Yes, caffeine has impressive pick-me-up powers - but it is also a diuretic that washes calcium and other key pregnancy nutrients out of your system before they can be thoroughly absorbed. Another downside to this diuretic effect: frequent urination, which is the last thing a pregnant woman needs (you will be peeing plenty on your own now that you are pregnant). What is more (and more motivation for cutting down on caffeine during pregnancy), caffeine stimulating effects may make those already delightful mood swings even more volatile and intense. 

 As for how caffeine during pregnancy affects your baby, although researchers know that it does enter the placenta, they are not certain about how much of an impact it has once it gets there. The latest information from the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists indicates that two cups of coffee a day (about 200mg per day) is okay, but heavier caffeine intake (in the range of five to six cups of coffee per day) slightly increases your risk of miscarriage. 

 So what should you do about the four-shot lattes that fuel your morning, or the Mountain Dews that recharge your afternoon battery when you are seriously sluggish? Since it is always best to err on the side of caution when you are expecting, consider cutting back caffeine to one or two (small) cups or cutting it out altogether. Horrified (and tired) at the thought? Here are some ways to make the process a little easier: 
 Remember why you are doing this. Of course, you know why you are skipping caffeine during pregnancy already - but it does not hurt to remind yourself (and pat yourself on the back) every time you (make it a decaf): It is good for your baby and it is good for you. 
 Figure out what you love best about your caffeine fix. Is it the taste of coffee you crave? That is easy - switch to a quality decaf brew and enjoy the flavor without the caffeine (even espresso comes decaf). Can not sparkle without carbonated sodas? Turn instead to sparkling water or sparkling juices (or sparkling caffeine-free sodas, but in moderation if they are full or sugar or artificially sweetened). Are you addicted to caffeine energy kick? Get a healthier energy boost from a snack of complex carbohydrates and proteins (you will get both from cheese and crackers or dried fruit and nuts), exercising regularly (even a ten-minute walk will give your energy level a jolt), and getting enough sleep (but not too much, which can actually make you more tired). 
 Know where it is hiding. Obviously, it is in the latte. And the iced Americano. And even the English breakfast (though in smaller amounts - one cup of tea contains 40 milligrams of caffeine, as opposed to the 100 or more milligrams in a cup of brewed coffee). But did you know that caffeine lurking in soft drinks (from colas to that Mountain Dew), energy drinks (where do you think that energy coming from?), and chocolate and coffee-flavored yogurt and ice cream (though again, in smaller amounts)? When counting up the caffeine in your day (and trying to limit it to those two cups - or 200 milligrams), make sure you add in all its sources. 
 Go gradually. Going from six cups to zero in a day will shock your system - and leave you exhausted, cranky, and headachy (the last thing you need on top of pregnancy fatigue). So shoot down those cold turkey plans - and take a gradual approach instead. Start by cutting down one cup a day until you are at the two cup-a-day mark (or keep going if you would like to be completely caffeine-free). If even that seems like too much too fast, stick with the same number of cups, but substitute decaf for half of each cup (you can keep the other half regular), and then slowly weaning yourself off both the taste and the kick of the real stuff by reducing the amount of regular and increasing the amount of decaf. Before you know it, your cups will be completely caffeine-free - or close to it. Another way to cut back on the caffeine in your cup: Make your own latte. Cut the coffee back to half a cup, and fill it to the brim with hot skim or low-fat milk. 
 Find energy the old-fashioned way. Eating smaller, more frequent meals and snacks (a good idea when you are pregnant, anyway - but an especially good idea when you are decaffeinating your system) will keep your energy up by keeping your blood sugar from dipping. Prenatal vitamins will also help you maintain your stamina without a caffeine fix. Now take that extra four bucks or so you spent on coffee every day (plus the money you spent on the accompanying doughnut du jour) and put it in an empty coffee cup. At the end of the week, treat yourself (manicure, anyone?)…you earned it!

Food Aversions During Pregnancy 


 Finding the incredible edible egg incredibly (and inexplicably) inedible at 5 weeks pregnant? Crying foul at the sight of chicken? Turning green at the salad bar? 

 Cravings may get all the press (and sitcom time), but a pregnant woman relationship with food is not just about what she wants - it is also about what she can not stand to eat, smell or even be in the same room with. Studies show that up to 85 percent of expectant mothers experience some kind of food aversion (most often in the first trimester), and if you are in that group you know that aversion is a mild word for such a strong response. As always, you can blame hormones (though there are probably other factors at work - including a largely outdated biological mechanism that in pre-fridge days protected women from foods that were most likely to be contaminated). 

 If you are lucky, your aversions will steer you clear only of foods (and beverages) you should not be eating (or drinking) right now anyway - like tuna sashimi, imported brie, double espressos, or single malt scotch. If you are not so lucky (and much more typical), they will also send you running from foods that contain important baby-friendly nutrients. 

 Fortunately, there is never a need to come fork-to-face with a food you can not stomach (or even speak the name of). You can easily avenge your aversions without compromising your nutritional ideals - just by practicing the fine art of substitution. 
 Is no egg a good egg these days? Are you chickening out when it comes to poultry? Do you have a serious beef with, well, beef? Many women experience an early pregnancy aversion to these classic protein foods (particularly those that qualify as (flesh foods)). Happily, there are plenty of protein sources residing outside the animal kingdom, including soy (soy pasta, tofu, edamame), nuts and legumes, beans, and certain grains (especially quinoa and couscous). Or is it just the sight of that slab of meat or chicken (or those sunny-side eggs eyeing you from the plate) that is turning your tummy? Consider hiding what you find offensive. Add ground beef to your casserole (extra lean will offer a milder flavor), minced chicken to your pasta dish or soup, egg to your pancakes. 
 Got a milk aversion? Skip the mustache (and the nausea), and get your calcium via a variety of other dairy products - from cheese to yogurt. Still too close for comfort? Sneak that offensive white liquid into smoothies or soups. Is anything that comes from a cow on your hit list? Strike the dairy for now, and substitute calcium-fortified juices, soy (such as tofu and edamame), sesame seeds, collard greens (though they are likely on your list, too), and canned salmon mashed with the bones (you will never know they are in there - especially once you have transformed the fish into a tasty croquette). Even broccoli and cooked dried beans will give you a healthy (and milk-free) calcium bonus. 
 Ready to toss your cookies over that tossed salad? Toss the salad - and any other green vegetable that is making you see red! Instead, paint your produce palate with yellow and orange. Carrots and yams are even richer in beta-carotene than their green comrades, but are usually a whole lot easier to handle (especially when grated or blended into muffins, cakes, and soups). Have not met a vegetable you have liked since the pregnancy test came back positive? Pick fruits, instead, to fill your nutritional requirements - especially such beta-carotene blockbusters as cantaloupe, mango, papaya, and apricots, many of which also pack a significant side of C.

Morning Sickness and Nausea During Pregnancy 


 Stick to foods that appeal, for now. Even if it is the same foods over and over and over again. Avoid eating (or seeing, or smelling, or even thinking about) any dishes that trigger the queasies (spicy and acidic foods may be particularly challenging, as well as anything with a strong aroma). Chances are you will be able to find a few healthy foods that you can keep down, or at least contemplate coming fork-to-face with - and that will take care of most of your nutritional requirements until a more varied diet becomes palatable. Choose only sweet foods if they are all you can tolerate (get your vitamin A and protein from peaches and yogurt at dinner instead of broccoli and chicken). Or select only savories if they are your ticket to a less tumultuous tummy (have reheated pizza for breakfast instead of cereal). Do not worry too much about getting your daily dozen in the short term; there will be plenty of time later on in your pregnancy for eating well. And remember, no one food has a monopoly on any one nutrient - so if you turn green at the thought of anything green, get your vitamin fix from sweet, juicy cantaloupe instead. 
 Eat early… Morning sickness does not wait for you to get up in the morning. In fact, nausea is most likely to strike when you are running on empty, as you are after a long night sleep. That is because when you have not eaten in a while, the acids churning around inside your empty tummy have nothing to digest but your stomach lining - which, not surprisingly, increases queasiness. To head off heaving, stock your nightstand full of trail mix, crackers and cold cereal to munch on first thing in the morning. It is a good idea to even have a little nocturnal nibble if (or rather, when) you wake up in the middle of the night to pee just so your stomach stays a little full all night long. 
 …and right before bed. For the same reason, try eating a light snack high in protein and complex carbs (a whole grain muffin and a glass of milk, string cheese and a handful of freeze-dried mango) just before you go to sleep to help ensure a happier tummy when you wake up. 
 Eat often. The idea is to keep your belly a little bit filled all the time (do not overfill it, and do not let it get completely empty). Eat six mini-meals throughout the day rather than three large ones - again, when your tummy is empty, you are more likely to feel nauseous. Plus, smaller meals are easier to digest - and less likely to trigger the queasies and heartburn, another classic pregnancy symptom. And do not leave your house without a healthy stash of snacks that your tummy can handle (dried fruit and nuts, granola bars, dry cereal, whole grain crackers or soy chips). 
 Eat well. A pregnancy diet high in protein and complex carbohydrates (like whole grain toast and peanut butter, or hard cheese and crackers) is not only good for baby, it can help keep nausea at bay. Steer clear of greasy and processed fast foods, which are hard to digest and can aggravate your nausea. 
 Switch off. Often, what starts out as a comfort food (it is the only thing you can keep down, so you eat it 24/7) becomes associated with nausea - and actually starts to trigger it. If you are so sick of crackers that they are actually beginning to make you sick, switch off to another comforting carb (maybe it will be Cheerios or watermelon next). 
 Drink up. In the short term, getting enough fluids is more important than getting enough solids, particularly if vomiting is leaving you high, dry and dehydrated. Can not stand water? Try sucking on Popsicles. Some women find that drinking and eating at the same sitting puts too much strain on their digestive tract; if this is true for you, try taking fluids between meals. If you are finding liquids are easier to get down when you are green, drink your vitamins and nutrients with soups, smoothies and shakes (many women find icy cold fluids and foods are easier to get down, too). If you find fluids make you queasier, eat solids with a high water content, like fruits and veggies, especially melons and citrus fruits. Both electrolyte water and coconut water may be especially helpful if you are vomiting a lot. 
 Smell (and see) no evil. Thanks to a much more sensitive sense of smell, pregnant women often find once-appetizing aromas suddenly offensive - and offensive ones downright sickening. So stay away from smells that trigger nausea - whether it is the sausage and eggs your partner likes to make on the weekends or the cologne that used to make you head over heels (but now makes you head for the toilet). Steer clear, too, of foods that you can not stand the sight of (raw chicken is a common culprit). 
 Supplement. Take your prenatal vitamin to compensate for nutrients you may not be getting, at whatever time of day you are least likely throw it back up. Take it with a meal, and consider a coated, powder or chewable one, which may agree with your stomach more. Afraid that vitamins will only be hard to choke down and make matters worse? Actually, that one-a-day can decrease nausea symptoms (especially if you take a slow-release vitamin that is higher in quease-combatting vitamin B6). If your symptoms are particularly rough, ask your practitioner about taking a vitamin B6 supplement (with or without Unisom SleepTabs, or another OTC version of the antihistamine doxylamine) and/or supplementing with magnesium (or using a magnesium spray), which some say can help ease nausea. 
 Tread gingerly. It is true what midwives have been saying for centuries: Ginger can be good for what ails a queasy pregnant woman. It is been shown in more than one study to reduce nausea and vomiting in pregnancy. So stock up on staples made with real ginger, such as ginger snaps, ginger ale (check the label; not all are made with real ginger), ginger tea, ginger candies, ginger biscuits, crystallized ginger or ginger drinks. Use ginger when you are cooking (ginger carrot soup, ginger muffins), and infuse your tea with it. Even the smell of fresh ginger (cut open a knob and take a whiff) may quell the queasies. 
 When life gives you morning sickness, make lemonade. Another trick of the queasy trade: lemons. Many women find the smell - and taste - of lemons comforting. Sour sucking candies or a sniff of freshly-cut lemon may be your ticket to relief. 
 Try Sea-bands. These 1-inch wide bands worn on both arms put pressure on acupressure points in the inner wrist. They cause no side effects, are widely available at drug and health food stores and have been shown to lessen pregnancy nausea. Your practitioner may also recommend a more sophisticated form of acupressure: a battery-operated wristband that uses electronic stimulation, like Relief Bands or Psi Bands. 
 Rest and de-stress. Both can help minimize queasiness. Try classic stress-reduction techniques, like meditation and visualization or prenatal yoga, and try to hit the sack for as many hours as you can clock every night. 
 Go slow-mo. Do not jump out of bed and dash out the door, since rushing tends to aggravate nausea. Instead, linger in bed for a few minutes, nibbling on a bedside snack, then rise slowly to a leisurely breakfast. It may seem impossible if you have other kids, but try to wake up before they do so you can sneak in quiet time (or let your partner take the morning shift). 
 Try alternative remedies. There are a wide variety of complementary medical approaches, such as acupuncture, acupressure, biofeedback or hypnosis, that can help minimize the symptoms of morning sickness - and they are all worth a try. 
 Treat your mouth well. Brush your teeth or rinse your mouth after bouts of vomiting if you can stomach it when your tummy has settled a bit, as well as after each meal. (Ask your dentist to recommend a good rinse, or use plain water; you can also brush your teeth with water or a milder tasting toothpaste if your usual brand is contributing to the nausea.) Not only will this help keep your mouth fresh and reduce queasiness in the future, it will decrease the risk of damage to teeth that can occur when bacteria feast on regurgitated residue in your mouth. 
 Ask your doctor about medication. If your morning sickness is severe, you may want to talk to your doctor about taking an FDA-approved prescription drug to treat nausea and vomiting during pregnancy that is been proven safe and effective. Do not take any medication (traditional or herbal) for morning sickness unless it is prescribed by your practitioner. 

 What causes morning sickness? 
 Hormone Levels 
 Higher-than-average levels (as when a woman is carrying multiples) can increase morning sickness; lower levels may minimize or eliminate it (though women with normal hormone levels may also experience little or no morning sickness). 
 Sensitivity 
 Some brains have a nausea command post that is more sensitive than others, which means they are more likely to respond to hormones and other triggers of pregnancy queasiness. If you have a sensitive stomach (you always get carsick or seasick, for instance), you are more likely to have more severe nausea and vomiting in pregnancy. Never have a queasy day ordinarily? You are less likely to have lots of them when you are expecting. 
 Stress 
 It is well known that emotional stress can trigger gastrointestinal upset, so it is not surprising that symptoms of morning sickness tend to worsen when stress strikes. That is not to say that morning sickness is in your head - it is where your head is (as in super stressed out) that can intensify it. 
 Fatigue Physical or mental fatigue can also exacerbate the symptoms of morning sickness (and conversely, severe morning sickness can increase fatigue). 
 First-time pregnancy status 
 Morning sickness is more common and tends to be more severe in first pregnancies, which supports the idea that both physical and emotional factors may be involved. Physically, the novice pregnant body is less prepared for the onslaught of hormones and other changes it is experiencing than one that is been there, done that. Emotionally, first timers are more likely to be subject to the kinds of anxieties and fears that can turn a stomach - while women in subsequent pregnancies may be distracted from their nausea by the demands of caring for older children. (Generalities never hold true for every expectant mom, though, and some women are queasier in subsequent pregnancies than they were in their first). 
 Genetics 
 Women whose mothers had morning sickness have been shown to be more likely to develop the condition themselves. 

 Can morning sickness hurt my baby? 
 In the short term, not eating very much is not a problem: Your baby is fortunately teeny tiny when morning sickness is at its worst and does not have very much in the way of nutritional needs yet. (By the time he or she does, you will almost certainly have your appetite back, in spades!) Even women who have such a hard time keeping food down that they actually lose weight during the first trimester are not hurting their babies, as long as they make up for the lost weight, as needed, in later months. Keep an eye on your urine, though: It should be clear or light-colored, like straw, not dark (which is a sign to drink up). 
 If you are not able to keep anything down, including fluids, however, it may be a symptom of hyperemesis gravidarum - a more serious condition which affects up to 5 percent of women with morning sickness. If your nausea is continuous and severe and you vomit several times a day, make sure to see your doctor: You may require additional treatment to protect both you and your baby. 

 Is it bad if I have not had any morning sickness? 
 Morning sickness, like a craving for pickles and ice cream, is one of those truisms about pregnancy that is not necessarily true. While studies show that nearly three-quarters of all pregnant women experience nausea and/or vomiting of pregnancy, that means a little more than 25 percent do not. If you are among those who never have a nauseous moment, or you only occasionally feel mildly queasy, consider yourself not only pregnant but also lucky!

Food Substitutions During Pregnancy 

 Cravings. Aversions. Gas. Morning sickness. You are 7 weeks pregnant, and all of a sudden it is open house for digestive distress (they are like the guests who wwll not leave the party - and this party got almost six months to go!). It figures that just when you care most about getting the right nutrients into your body, your body is trying every trick in the book to keep them out. Luckily, your brain can outsmart your body by subbing healthy equivalents for the unhealthy foods you crave, the ones you can not down (or keep down), or the ones that make you feel like a flotation device. Try the following bait-and-switches next time pregnancy symptoms get in the way of eating well. 
 Cravings: Some expectant moms love sweets and some love salt (and some have room in their hearts - and stomachs - for both), but sometimes there is such a thing as loving too much. Luckily, for every sweet or salty junk food on the menu, there is a healthier choice that (coupled with a little, or sometimes a lot, of willpower) can keep your taste buds - and your baby - happy. Waiting for your chip to come in? Do not wait - just substitute soy chips or baked potato or taco chips for greasy varieties. Or munch your way through some air-popped popcorn (tossed with some Parmesan for that salty kick you crave), rice cakes, pretzels, or lightly salted edamame. Is your inner chocoholic clamoring to come out? Satisfy it with a cup of hot chocolate (that you have made with skim milk) or a single-serving Fudgsicle instead of that king-sized Snickers. You are screaming for ice cream? Scream for frozen yogurt instead (and top yours with fresh berries to score nutritional brownie points). 
 Aversions: You know you need your protein, but you have had a falling out with meat (and chicken, and fish…) - and now you can not be in the same room together, never mind share a plate. You will eventually patch up the relationship, but until then, pick up protein from more palatable sources, including cottage cheese, yogurt, beans, or soy products (especially tofu or edamame). Or consider quinoa, a nutty grain that packs a super punch of protein in a comforting package. If it is leafy greens that turn you a not-so-delicate shade of chartreuse, become a yellow belly. Yellow vegetables are often easier to take, so try carrots or yams, or go for the beta-carotene in cantaloupe, mango, peaches, and apricots. 
 Gas: It is like a cosmic joke - some of the healthiest foods can leave you gassier than the Goodyear blimp … and not at all in the mood to eat your veggies. Opt instead for healthy substitutions that will not bring on the bloat (mango instead of broccoli, strawberries instead of cabbage). Pop bagel chips instead of potato chips, and poached chicken breast instead of those once-beloved chicken fingers. And here is a really simple way to deflate those tummy bubbles: Instead of sparkling water, opt for plain. 
 Morning sickness: Still suffering from morning sickness (which sadly is not limited to the mornings at all, unless you count mornings in every time zone)? Will you scream if you even have to look at another saltine? Fortunately, you have options. Dry and bland are the key here, but that describes more than a cracker: Dry cereal, pretzels, rice cakes, well-toasted bread, and bread sticks are all suitable for the bedside table (watch out for crumbs in your bed) or handbag stashing.

Food Cravings During Pregnancy 


 Have a sudden yen for yams? A hankering for hotcakes (strangely, enough, layered with Swiss cheese and strawberry jam)? A longing for lychee nuts (preferably dipped in honey mustard)? A passion for, well, passion fruit? Welcome to the peculiar club of pregnancy cravings. It may be the oldest cliché in the book (and on TV), but, as you have discovered (halfway through that pint of dulce de leche that you have smothered in chopped black olives), it is true. Pregnancy cravings do drive expectant mothers (and their spouses) to extraordinary lengths - like to the Quickie Mart for a 1 a.m. refill on salsa and green apples. 

 What fuels these seemingly inexplicable dietary eccentricities, which strike more than three-quarters of pregnant women? As always, hormones can likely take a good deal of the blame - especially since the most out-of-whack cravings peak during your hormonally charged first trimester. Another theory is that cravings are your body way of sending you instant messages about your nutritional needs - dispatching you to the fridge for a guzzle of orange juice when you are short of C, or to the grill for a steak when your iron stores are low. (That theory, though, probably held more water - and OJ - before processed foods and candy bars became such a prominent force on the food chain. These days, the signals may be a little scrambled. After all, what exactly is your body telling you when you crave a Kit Kat bar?) 

 So what should you do when cravings strike? That depends, of course, on exactly what the craving for. Here are some tactics for getting the best from your cravings: 
 Give in. If you are lucky enough to be craving fruit or vegetables - dig in with abandon. Try to vary things a bit if you can (toss a few blueberries or strawberries in with your mango madness), but do not worry if your taste buds will not take the bait. Same goes for a hamburger habit (especially if that is all you can get down). Just try to mix up the grill by adding a few key nutritious toppings (a whole grain bun, sliced tomato and lettuce, a slice of cheese) and a fruit cup on the side. 
 Substitute. If your cravings are sending you spoon first into a bowl of sugar-frosted cereal, look to satisfy your sweet tooth a healthier way. Eat a low-sugar whole-grain cereal (like Cheerios) topped with fresh strawberries and bananas, and maybe a drizzle of honey. Would you sell your soul for a bag of kettle-cooked potato chips? Save it instead by baking up some potato chips (red-skinned potatoes, drizzled with olive oil, sprinkled with a little salt and some parmesan cheese, and baked until crisp) or diving into a bag of soy crisps (they are crispy and tasty like the potato chips, but packed with protein you and your baby need). On a bread binge? That is easy - indulge, just make it whole wheat. 
 Distract. Get your mind off the Mallomars with a nonfood activity that you enjoy almost as much as cookies - whether it is taking a walk, chatting with a friend, surfing online, baking a batch of wholesome muffins, or picking up an engrossing novel. 
 Stay safe. If your cravings are for something you should not have now that you are expecting (like queso fresco or another kind of unpasteurized soft cheese, a rare burger, or sashimi), you will not be able to indulge yourself. Instead, sub something that comes as close as possible to the object of your affections (pasteurized feta, a well-done burger with extra toppings, teriyaki salmon). If you find yourself craving substances that are not food (like clay, ashes, or laundry starch), contact your practitioner, since such cravings could indicate a condition called pica triggered by a nutritional deficiency. (Make sure you know what foods to avoid during pregnancy.)

Energy Foods During Pregnancy 


 Too pooped to pop these days (or meet friends for dinner, or make it halfway down that to-do list, or actually stay up for a prime time special - never mind the late show)? Of course you are…you are pregnant!
