Eating Well on a Budget During Pregnancy 


 Worried that your healthy new diet is going to break the bank - just when you need every penny? Not to worry. You can eat royally at 23 weeks pregnant without spending like a queen; in fact, with a little forethought, you can eat low-cost meals and snacks that are even more wholesome than their pricier alternatives. 

 Balk at brand loyalty. Store brands and no-frills products may not seduce you with pretty packaging, but who cares? (Were you planning to use that cereal box as a centerpiece?) They are likely to have inner beauty to match their attractive price tags; check the labels and you will see they boast as much nutrition as the bigger brands. From juice and yogurt to bread and snacks, nearly every kind of packaged food (including the whole-grain ones) comes in a generic version, and you will find an abundance of options in the cereal and frozen food aisles. And here is a little-known secret: In many instances, the store brand is actually a name brand with a store label, so you may be buying the exact same bread you have known and loved - but for a lot less dough. 

 Brown-bag it. Bringing your lunch to work is win-win - you can feed that little bundle in your belly and save a bundle, too. Just do the math: You could spend between five and ten dollars on a take-out sandwich, side, and soft drink (and you do not know quite what you are getting), but the sandwich wrap you made from leftover roast chicken and veggies costs a fraction of that (and water from the cooler is free). Pack your wrap with a wedge of cheese and a piece of fruit, and you are good to go (without going to the deli come lunchtime). Brown-bag often enough and you could save hundreds of dollars by the time your baby is born - a great first deposit in the college fund! 

 Bulk up. By the case or by the pound, buying in quantity can save you big bucks. Seek out economy sizes of whatever is available - from meat you can freeze (why not cook it all first so you have ready-made meals?), to cereals, canned goods, and juice. But make sure your eyes are not bigger than your stomach - a crate of sweet potatoes may look like a sweet deal, unless they grow roots long before you can bake them. 

 Opt for H2O. The cheapest drink on the menu? Water. It is also the best choice for you and your baby. You can save dollars a day (not to mention considerable empty calories) by sacrificing the fancier drinks. In most cases, no need to buy bottled. Most tap water is safe to drink (but make sure first that there is no lead in your pipes or the water supply). To be extra safe, buy a filter for your tap or use filtered pitchers for your water. You can also make the most of your juice dollars by buying frozen concentrate instead of refrigerated cartons and reconstituting the concentrate with water. 

 Forgo the convenience factor. The introduction of frozen TV dinners revolutionized the way America eats, and not necessarily for the better. While plentiful, these quick-prep options often come with a significant price tag - not to mention the price you can pay in unhealthy additives and excesses in fat, sodium, and sugar. Same goes for bottled salad dressings, sauces, and just about anything marked (instant.) Save time and money by making big batches of your own meals and freezing them in individual servings. Dress your salads on the cheap and on the fly by whipping together a delicious dressing from extra-virgin olive oil (also available in bulk, but the shelf life is short), Dijon mustard, and fresh lemon juice (store it in an old mayonnaise jar in the fridge). Take the time (it is only five minutes!) to cook real oatmeal instead of popping those sugary packets into the microwave. You will save yourself money (and buy your baby a healthier breakfast).

Should You Eat an Organic Diet During Pregnancy? 


 Now that you are eating for two, you may be wondering whether if and when you should opt for organic foods. Organics, after all, are more expensive than non-organic, or conventional, food - but naturally you want to do everything possible to give your baby the best start to life. So is buying organic worth it? 
 Like every debate - and the organic food vs. conventional food controversy is far from being settled - there are pros and cons. According to the American Academy of Pediatrics, organic foods are less harmful to the environment and do result in less exposure to pesticides, but there is no proof that eating an organic diet has any actual health benefits over a conventional diet. So if there is no proof, does that mean organic food is not a good way to spend your money? Not necessarily. Is it right for you? It is totally your choice - but this information might help. 

 What Does (Organic) Mean? 
 The United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) has a set of standards that food labeled organic must meet, regardless of whether the food is grown in the U.S. or elsewhere. These standards stipulate the manner in which such food is grown, handled and processed, and that means: 
 No pesticides 
 No chemical fertilizers 
 No weed-killers 
 Can not be genetically modified 
 Does not receive hormones or antibiotics (for chicken, beef and pork) 
 To add to the confusion, the USDA Organic Seal guidelines can be a bit tricky to interpret. For example: 
 Foods labeled 100-percent organic must contain only organically produced raw or processed products 
 Foods labeled organic must contain at least 95 percent organically produced ingredients (excluding water and salt) 
 Foods labeled made with organic ingredients must contain 70 percent organic ingredients 
 Foods that are only labeled organic on the ingredient side label, not the main label, contain less than 50 percent organic ingredients 

 Why You Should Consider Eating Organic 
 The research is ongoing - and controversial - but some studies have shown that organic foods may help you to avoid: 
 Pesticides: A large-scale study by Environmental Health Perspectives showed that eating organic foods decreases the amount of pesticides we consume. No definitive study, however, has actually linked consumption of specific pesticides with any adverse long-term health effects for you or your baby. While more research needs to be done on the effect of pesticides on humans, it is interesting to note that glyphosate, one of most popular weed-killers used throughout the world (and widely within the U.S.) has been labeled a probable carcinogen by the International Agency for Research on Cancer, the France-based cancer research arm of the World Health Organization (WHO). (Glyphosate was found in the blood and urine of agricultural workers who are exposed to large amounts of the chemical, not consumers.) The US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), however, ruled in 2012 that glyphosate was safe for use on American crops. 
 Antibiotics: More research needs to be done on the long-term effects of antibiotics given to animals and then consumed by humans. But the risk is that, over a long period of time, certain bacteria in the animals we eat will become immune to the antibiotics we routinely feed them. If people, in turn, eat improperly cooked meat and become ill with this antibiotic-resistant bacteria, antibiotics may not cure the infection. This has led European countries and Canada - but not the United States - to ban certain antibiotics in agriculture. USDA-certified organic meat, however, does not contain antibiotics. 
 Additives: When buying ready-made foods, choosing organic varieties means avoiding artificial colorings, flavorings and preservatives. There has been controversy around whether these are linked to conditions including attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), which some studies and the Center for Science in the Public Interest have claimed. But the FDA says that current research shows there is not a link between food coloring and behavior problems in kids, though there may be in those who are already susceptible to ADHD.

 The Downsides of Eating Organic 
 In addition to cost (organics can be up to double the price of conventional foods!), other downsides include: 
 Shelf Life: Preservatives are meant to, well, preserve. That means their shelf life is much longer than organic products. Bread and other staples will often have earlier expiration dates if they are preservative-free. 
 Taste: Think organic produce always tastes better than conventional produce? That may not be the case. The National Institutes of Health Consumer sensory analysis of organically and conventionally-grown vegetables did not show any significant difference in taste quality for most produce - with the exception of tomatoes, where conventional surprisingly scored higher. 

 When to Shop – and When to Skip – Organic 
 On a budget? Prefer to pick and choose which foods to buy organic, instead of diving in head-first? In that case, it is all about (The Dirty Dozen,) the 12 fruits and vegetables deemed to be most contaminated with pesticides by the Environmental Working Group: 
 Apples 
 Strawberries 
 Grapes 
 Celery 
 Peaches 
 Spinach 
 Sweet bell peppers 
 Nectarines (imported) 
 Cucumbers 
 Cherry tomatoes 
 Snap peas (imported) 
 Potatoes 

 Additional better-to-buy-organic foods include: 
 Organic grass-fed meat, which in addition to being free of antibiotics has been shown to be lower in calories and fat and higher in protein than conventional meat 
 Organic, free-range poultry and eggs, since free-range chickens are also less likely to carry salmonella (because they are not kept in cramped, disease-breeding quarters) 

 Going Conventional 
 On the bright side (yes, there is a bright side!), there is also a (Clean 15) list of those fruits and vegetables with the lowest pesticide amounts. These are foods where buying conventional is totally fine: 
 Avocados 
 Sweet corn 
 Pineapples 
 Cabbage 
 Sweet peas (frozen) 
 Onions 
 Asparagus 
 Mangoes 
 Papayas 
 Kiwi 
 Eggplant 
 Grapefruit 
 Cantaloupe (domestic) 
 Cauliflower 
 Sweet potatoes Tips for Buying Organic 
 Here is how to get the best nutritional bang for your buck on organic items: 
 Check out organic coupon sites including Mambo Sprouts, Organic Deals and Healthesavers, and follow local health food stores on social media. 
 When organic items are on sale, buy double the amount and freeze the leftovers. 
 Shop around: Organic is now widely available. In addition to your local grocery store, many big-box stores have an organic section. 
 Skip the pre-wash and pre-cut organic items; when the work is done for you, it makes already-expensive organic foods even more expensive. So instead of buying organic baby carrots, but organic regular size carrots for half the price and do the washing and cutting yourself. 
 Choose store brands that say (organic) on the main label (if it says (organic,) it needs to follow the organic guidelines in the USDA organic certification program). 
 Keep in mind, too, that organic does not necessarily mean nutritious. Organic white bread is still, after all, white bread - as are organic cookies made with refined flour and sugar. Check the labels: The overall nutritional value of your choice is more important than whether its ingredients are organic. 

 Bottom line: Opt for organic produce when it is practical, but remember that what is most important in the produce aisle is choosing a wide variety of fresh, ripe fruits and veggies in a range of colors. And never assume that organic means completely safe. Though it will not be treated with pesticides, organic foods can still be contaminated with bacteria. So whether you buy organic or conventional, cook your meat, poultry and fish thoroughly and wash your produce meticulously before eating it.

Not Gaining Enough Weight During Pregnancy: 5 Tips to Get Back on Track 


 For most women, pregnancy weight gain comes all too easily. But for others, the problem is not gaining too much weight - it is not gaining enough. Whether due to metabolism, body issues, morning sickness, appetite loss or another medical reason, not gaining enough weight can put you at greater risk of pregnancy complications. In fact, babies whose mothers gain under 20 pounds during pregnancy are more likely to be born early, small for their gestational age and to suffer growth restriction in the uterus. (The exception: very overweight women, who can safely gain less than 20 pounds under close medical supervision.) 

 That said, many women have trouble putting on an ounce in the early weeks - some even lose a few pounds. Fortunately nature has your baby back, offering protection even if you are too queasy or food-averse to eat. Tiny fetuses have tiny nutritional needs, which means that your lack of weight gain early on will not have any effect on your baby. 

 The same is not true if you are falling short of your recommended weight gain by the second trimester. As your baby gets bigger, calories and nutrients will be more and more in demand - and you will want to kick your weight gain efforts into high gear, piling on the pounds at a steady pace. 

 But do not stress if you are not gaining the advised weight: Your doctor or a nutritionist can help create a meal plan for you. In the meantime, here are a few tips to help you put on the right amount of weight during pregnancy: 
 Eat more calories. It sounds obvious, but it is worth repeating. If you are eating the right amount of calories during pregnancy and you are not gaining weight fast enough, you need to take in more - considerably more if your weight gain has been particularly slow. If you have lost your appetite, focus on quality calories in small packages. Good options include foods high in healthy fats, such as avocados and nuts, as well as higher-calorie grains and legumes (denser whole-wheat breads, heartier whole-grain cereals, pasta, beans and peas). 
 Skip big salads and other caloric bargains for now. Save them for after your main course to avoid putting a damper on your appetite. Instead, go for more concentrated sources of nutrients and calories - e.g., dried apricots instead of broccoli. 
 Do not turn to junk or processed foods. While it might be tempting to fill the caloric gap (and your frame) with doughnuts, resist. Sugary treats (or greasy fries) will add weight - but not nutrition, and you are looking for both. (Get more pregnancy nutrition tips here.) 
 Eat early, late and often. Instead of eating three (larger) square meals a day, try to eat six smaller snack-sized bites every two hours or so - and make them count. Good choices: trail mix, granola, cheese, whole-grain muffins, guacamole or hummus with pita chips, bagels with peanut or almond butter, baked sweet potato fries. Do not feel like eating? Make yourself a thick, rich, sustaining smoothie, and fortify it with some wheat germ . 
 Slow down. Have a vigorous exercise routine? Take it down a few notches (the more calories you burn, the harder time you will have putting on pounds). Switch from hard-core water aerobics to gentle laps, from jogging to strolling. If it is your busy schedule that is keeping you on the run (and keeping you from eating enough and often enough), slow that down too. 

 In extreme cases, some women develop a condition called hyperemesis gravidarum, or severe and continuous vomiting and nausea that is more debilitating than regular morning sickness. If you have it, you will not be able to keep anything down, which is problematic because not only are you not getting the vital nutrients and vitamins you and your baby need, you may also be dehydrated. The condition is more common in women carrying multiples or those who have a history of motion sickness. If you think you might be suffering from hyperemesis gravidarium, be sure to let your doctor know. She may prescribe medication or lifestyle changes depending on the severity.

Too Busy to Eat Healthy During Pregnancy? 


 Time not on your side? Join the club. Rare is the pregnant woman who is not time-challenged these days - and challenged by the prospect of eating well while running the 14-hour marathon that is called daily life. Sure, it would be a piece of cake (make that a piece of grilled chicken, a scoop of brown rice, a salad, and a fruit cup) to nourish yourself and your baby if there were more than ten minutes to prepare meals (and more than four and a half minutes to eat them)…in other words, if eating well were the only item on your to-do plate. When there are so many other items competing for your time - and attention - it is a whole lot tougher. Yet, as you already know at 26 weeks pregnant, eating well when you are eating for two is twice as important. Fortunately, no matter how fast-paced your world is, these strategies can help you squeeze in the nutrition you and your baby need. 

 Shop smart. Before you race through the aisles to fill your cart with what most quickly catches your eye (which is more likely to be a carton of fudge ripple than a couple of cantaloupe), make a list of healthy staples you will need to get you through the week, such as yogurt, pre shredded or sliced low-fat cheese, milk, plenty of fruits and vegetables, whole grains (ready-to-eat cereal, bread, pitas and wraps, brown rice, couscous, quinoa), nuts, lean meats, poultry, and legumes. You may want to buy nonperishable items in bulk so you can store them in the pantry for the weeks ahead (saving yourself another trip to the store). But when it comes to produce, snacks, and dairy products, think small, convenient, and ready-to-nibble - look for single-serve six- or eight-packs of yogurt, eight-ounce tubs of cottage cheese, individually wrapped string cheese, pre-cut fresh fruit salads, mini packs of baby carrots, small boxes or bags of raisins, nuts, dried fruit, and trail mix. And do not forget to load up on small bottles of water and cans of tomato or vegetable juice. That way no matter how busy you are, you can grab and go with a nutritious bite (and sip) in hand. Other shortcuts you should definitely take: using frozen vegetables and fruits, ready washed bags of salad, and fast-cooking cuts of meat and poultry (for stir-fry or fajitas). (Get even more grocery-store savvy with this smart shopping during pregnancy guide.) 

 Speed up your kitchen. If a 30-minute meal takes 20 minutes more than you have got, you need a speedy kitchen at your service. Make sure you have the right gear on hand, and use it. Your microwave can do more than warm a cup of tea: It reheats your leftovers, defrosts your frozens in a flash, and can even be used to cook a whole dinner! On the flip side, a slow cooker can be your best time-saver. Do not let the name fool you: Toss in whatever you have in the house (meat, beans, veggies, broth) in the morning, turn it on, and come home at the end of the day to a delicious hot meal (with plenty of leftovers for tomorrow). Cleanup is a breeze, too. Just rinse the pot and run it through the dishwasher (check your directions first). Rely on your blender to produce smoothies in a few seconds, your food processor to chop everything before you count to five, and a toaster oven to warm (or melt) anything in less time than it takes to preheat your oven. 

 Plan ahead. Your freezer is your friend; cook once and fill it many times over with nutritious leftovers. It is just as easy (easier, even) to make a large tray of lasagna as it is to make a single plateful (layer it up with defrosted frozen spinach or broccoli, that pre shredded low-fat cheese, a good quality jarred tomato sauce, and ground lean beef or ground turkey). Slice the leftovers into individual portions and then freeze to reheat and feast another day (and another, and another). The same goes for soups, so why not make a vat of minestrone (chock-full of beans, carrots, and whole-wheat pastas) and freeze in single-serve containers (that you can reheat later as a nourishing snack)? Ditto stews, mini meat loaves, muffins - you name it. For the fridge, boil a dozen eggs at a time: Mash half into egg salad (for lunch today and tomorrow) and keep the rest intact for snacks on the run (or snacks to keep you going while you make dinner). Cut up enough fruit salad or crudités to keep you happily and healthily munching for days. And instead of grilling one chicken breast for dinner, grill four or more; the rest will make delicious sandwiches, dinner salad toppings, or fajita fillings in the days to come. 

 Get out. If you can not take the heat, get out of the kitchen. Stop at the market for a rotisserie chicken and a tray filled from the salad bar or order in from your friendly local takeout (preferably a healthy one). No time even for those maneuvers? Grab whatever is in the fridge and pantry and call it a meal (who says it can not be two yogurts, a banana, and a cup of dry cereal for lunch or last night cold chicken and asparagus, nibbled straight from the container, for dinner?). And if you can not even eat and run, eat on the run - tuck your refrigerated items into a cold pack for a meal on the go.

Safety in the Kitchen During Pregnancy 


 You have already said so long to rare steaks, sayonara to sashimi, and adieu to your favorite French brie. (Fortunately, you will not be apart for long - as soon as your baby is born, you will be able to welcome them back into your diet with open arms, and open mouth.) Out the kitchen door, too, is a casual approach to meal prep - there is never been a time when food handling has been more important (not that you would ever want a case of food poisoning - but you definitely want to avoid one now). Fear not: Preparing food safely is fairly easy if you take your lead from the local health department and follow a few common sense rules. (These habits will serve you well when you are trying to keep your child food safe, too - so consider using them for keeps.) 

 Wash up. That goes for your hands first and foremost, and also for your dish towels, countertops, sponges - everything that is even remotely a part of the food prep process, including the food itself. Anything you plan to eat, and anything that touches what you plan to eat, should be kept spick-and-span. Be extra vigilant about this when handling raw meats, eggs, poultry, or fish - wash your hands with warm, soapy water before and after you touch these foods, and be sure to clean your hands immediately after you have finished, along with the utensils, cutting board, and towels you handled along the way. Wash the lids of cans before you open them so dirt and bacteria will not contaminate the contents (and never eat anything from a dented can - but that is true whether you are pregnant or not). Wash fruits and veggies thoroughly before eating them, even the ones you intend to peel. The one exception to the wash before using rule: Do not rinse raw meat or poultry. You will not be washing off the bacteria - only cooking can eliminate that - but you will be splashing the bacteria all over the sink and countertop. 

 Hot means hot, cold means cold. Keep uncooked perishable foods at or below 40°F, and do not let them stay above 40°F for more than two hours. Refrigerate any fresh food that will not be served or cooked immediately. On the flip side, keep hot foods at or above 140°F until serving, and do not leave them sitting out on the table while you linger over coffee. Refrigerate them immediately, and reheat leftovers thoroughly (until steaming or boiling). Having a hot weather picnic? Limit the time your perishables spend sitting out to one hour. 

 Make it well-done. When it comes to meat, fish, or poultry, half-baked is not baked enough for you. Pierce your cooked chicken - if the juice comes out red, it is undercooked, so put it back in the oven and let it heat up till the fluid runs clear. Cut through the thickest part of cooked meat and chops to make sure the middle is gray or brown, and not a speck is rare. And instead of searing fish and serving it rare or medium, bake, broil, grill, or poach it until it is cooked through. Better still, check the temperature (with a quality meat thermometer, not the back of your hand) of anything you make to be sure it is cooked through. Remember these (fully cooked) temperatures of some family favorites: 
 Whole chicken or turkey: 180°F 
 Beef, veal, lamb, or pork, roasts, chops, or steaks: 145°F 
 Chicken breasts: 170°F 
 Ground chicken or turkey: 165°F 
 Ground beef, veal, lamb, pork: 160°F 
 Fish: 145°F 
 Precooked ham: 140°F 

 Be (eggs-acting.) Choose cage-free eggs, when possible, and only buy ones that have been kept refrigerated. Throw away any that have cracked, and keep even your cooked eggs in the fridge at all times. When preparing eggs, cook until the whites have set firmly and the yolks have begun to thicken. And of course, never consume them raw (in salad dressings, sauces, or mousse-type desserts), unless you are using the pasteurized variety. If you are using raw, unpasteurized eggs for baking, resist the temptation to lick that raw batter.

Eating Fish During Pregnancy: What is Safe and What Is not 


 If you are unsure of the rules on fish and pregnancy, you are not alone: There is been plenty of conflicting views over the years. Fish is heart healthy! But wait, it is also full of mercury. Fish is loaded with baby-friendly DHA! But not so fast - it is also loaded with PCBs. So what is the real dish on fish? The bottom line is that eating enough of the right types is not only healthy but recommended for both you and your baby. Here’s the lowdown on what is safe and what is not when it comes to seafood. 

 How Much Fish You Should Eat 
 So how much seafood should you eat during pregnancy? In 2014 and again 2016, the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) released joint statements encouraging moms to eat more pregnancy-safe fish. The groups said that expecting and breastfeeding women should eat 8 to 12 ounces (that is two to three servings) of low-mercury fish every week. 

 Fish to Avoid During Pregnancy 
 Though the benefits of fish are many, you should still avoid a few types during pregnancy. Some - particularly large, ocean-faring, predator-types - contain high levels of mercury, a distinctly baby-unfriendly toxin. Others - especially those that live in polluted lakes and rivers - can be laden with PCBs, a chemical you definitely do not want to feed a fetus or an infant. 

 To play it safe, the latest FDA and EPA recommendations suggest avoiding or limiting the following fish while you are pregnant and nursing: Avoid 
 It is best to avoid these seven types of fish, which are all higher in mercury: tilefish from the Gulf of Mexico, shark, swordfish, orange roughy, bigeye tuna, marlin and king mackerel. 
 Limit to one serving per week 
 The following fish are considered (good to eat,) which means you can safely eat one serving per week (that is approximately 4 ounces): Bluefish, buffalofish, carp, Chilean sea bass, grouper, halibut, mahi mahi, monkfish, rockfish, sablefish, sheepshead, snapper, spanish mackerel, striped bass (ocean), Tilefish from the Atlantic ocean, albacore white tuna (canned, fresh or frozen), yellowfin tuna, weakfish/seatrout and white croaker/Pacific croaker. 
 Exercise extra caution if you are planning to eat recreationally-caught fish: Check local state advisories for the waters where the fish was caught. If no information is available, stick to one serving of these fish per week, with skin and excess fat removed. 

 Safe Fish During Pregnancy 
 Despite the long list of fish to limit during pregnancy, the vast majority of fish you will find in the store and at restaurants are considered safe to eat when you are expecting at two to three servings (that is 8 to 12 ounces) per week. These include wild salmon, shrimp, catfish, tilapia, sole, flounder, haddock, halibut, ocean perch, pollock, cod, canned light tuna, crab, crawfish, lobster, hake, clams, black sea bass, anchovies and trout. 
 Heard conflicting advice on salmon, too? Salmon definitely one of nature best providers of DHA. But to ensure you are not also feasting on the high levels of PCBs often found in farmed salmon, opt for wild (which also contains more of those healthy omega-3 fats) or organic farmed salmon. 

 How to Properly Prepare Fish 
 By now you have probably heard that you should avoid sushi during pregnancy - and the same goes for any other raw (oysters, ceviche, smoked salmon) or undercooked fish, since they can contain bacteria and parasites (like Listeria) that are dangerous for your developing baby. 

 Here are a few tips to properly prepare fish and help reduce your exposure to any potential contaminants: 
 Buy only fresh, properly refrigerated seafood. Store it in the fridge in a sealed container if you are not cooking it immediately. 
 Use separate cutting boards for meats (including fish) and fruits/veggies. 
 Do not reuse marinades. 
 Cook seafood (all types, including shucked clams, oysters, shrimp, lobster and scallops) until it reaches an internal temperature of 145° F; if a thermometer is not available, you will know it is done when the flesh is opaque (milky white); fish fillets should flake easily with a fork. 
 Clams, mussels and oysters are cooked when their shells open; throw away any that do not. 

 The Benefits of Fish 
 The good news (at least for moms who enjoy seafood) is that fish really does offer big benefits for both pregnant women and their developing babies. Fish: 
 Supports fetal growth. Fish is a first-rate source of lean protein, an essential amino acid that helps create all of baby cells - from skin and muscle to hair and bones. 
 Is good for baby brain. What is more, fish (especially the fattier varieties, like salmon) is a source of the omega-3 fatty acid DHA, which has been shown to boost baby brain power. It is more important than ever in the third trimester, when your baby brain growth is fast and furious. 
 Boosts your memory. Speaking of boosted brain power, getting enough omega-3s may also improve your memory - especially helpful when you are battling a case of pregnancy brain. 
 Improves your mood: An adequate intake of omega-3 fatty acids and especially DHA has been shown to decrease your risk of depression during pregnancy as well as postpartum depression. 
 Supports your heart: A diet rich in fish may lower your risk of cardiac disease by reducing blood clotting and levels of triglycerides (blood fat) as well as lowering blood pressure if you have preexisting hypertension. 
 May reduce risk of preterm birth. Scientists have observed that rates of preterm birth are lower in areas with a high fish intake - and some studies have indeed linked adequate omega 3 intake (whether through fish or supplements) to a lower risk of preterm birth.

Good Fats vs. Bad Fats During Pregnancy 


 With the pregnancy pounds piling on at 29 weeks pregnant (as they should be), is fat the last word you feel like hearing right now? After all, most women who have ever been on a diet (in other words, most women) have come to fear that particular f-word - and to believe that nothing good can come from fat (you eat fat, you get fat). 

 And while that is all too true when it comes to unhealthy fats (the greasy ones that give fries their crunch, the creamy ones that sandwich Oreos), plenty of good can come from the right fat - especially when you are expecting. Those good fats can be your child very best friend (as well as yours) - and that friendship starts now, before your child is even born. 

 The most fabulous of fats? The omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids, most notably DHA (known in scientific circles as docosahexaenoic acid). While omega-3s are healthy additions to any diet (they lower cholesterol and blood pressure, reducing the risk of heart disease), they are particularly smart selections when you are building a baby. DHA, for instance, is a vital ingredient in brain and retinal tissue, so it is essential for proper brain growth and eye development in fetuses and young babies. During the third trimester, brain growth is at its peak - and it continues to grow during the first year of life, tripling in size by the time your baby is a year old. This means that your baby need for this must-have nutrient will skyrocket (the brain DHA content must multiply by three to five times during these busy three months). 

 Where will all this brain fuel come from? As always, the heat is on you to keep those supplies coming through your Pregnancy Diet. But a DHA-heavy diet can be a little tricky to follow, since so many fish are off-limits when you are expecting (get the whole story on eating fish during pregnancy). Luckily, DHA is found in safe-to-savor cold water, fatty fishes such as salmon (always choose wild when you can) and cod. 

 Have not found your sea legs? Try DHA-rich eggs, sometimes called omega-3 eggs. They are laid by chickens on a DHA-supplemented diet - it will say so on the package. Regular egg yolks contain a small amount of DHA, too. Vegans, fear not - algae is an all-natural plant source of DHA, so you can incorporate foods like seaweed into your diet. 

 These foods also contain a concentrated amount of DHA: 
 Anchovies 
 Herring 
 Sardines 
 Trout 
 Other oily fishes 

 Smaller, but still significant, amounts of DHA are in these foods: 
 Canned tuna (which you can safely eat six ounces of each week) 
 Crab 
 Shrimp

Healthy Snacks During Pregnancy 


 Are you too full for full-sized meals? Is that parking spot already taken? As your stomach starts losing the competition for space in your increasingly cramped abdomen at 30 weeks pregnant, polishing off the pasta or chowing down on chicken can definitely seem unappetizing and physically impossible. Fortunately, snacks can step in to save the day - and get you through the day, while supplying all the nutrients you need to put those important finishing touches on that baby of yours. In fact, when it comes to keeping a healthy Pregnancy Diet (especially in the third trimester), eating less food more often is most effective. Women who eat at least five times a day are more likely to carry to term (and less likely to carry around a bad case of bloat). Whether you call them big snacks or mini-meals, they should pack in maxi-nutrition (in other words, you should not use them as an excuse to grab a chocolate baby Bundt cake or a café latte - make sure you know what foods to avoid during pregnancy.) 

 Overhaul your approach to snack attacks, and turn them into frequent opportunities to feed yourself and your baby well. It is easy to make the most of your midday munchies. 

 Pack portables: No matter where your day takes you, make sure healthy snacks go along for the ride. Stock your fridge and pantry with plenty of nutritious nibbles, sized to fit in your purse, briefcase, pocket, glove compartment, desk drawer: 
 single serving of yogurts, smoothies, and cottage cheese 
 individually wrapped cheese wedges and string cheese 
 mini-tubs or cans of fruit packed in its own juice or ready-to-eat fruit salad 
 granola bars (choose whole-grain, low-sugar varieties) 
 mini-bags or boxes of raisins or nuts 
 fresh fruit that travels well (bananas, apples, and seedless tangerines or oranges) 
 nutritious drinks to wash it all down with (small cans of tomato or vegetable juice, juice containers, and milk boxes) 
 serving-size bags of soy chips, baked corn chips, and whole-grain pretzels and crackers (to crunch alongside your cheese 
 precut carrots and celery sticks (some even come with dip) 
 healthy soups-in-a-cup, if you have a microwave or some hot water handy (you will find them, and other notably nutritious convenience foods, in the health food section of your market) 

 Can not find those good things in small packages? Package them yourself - load up on ziplock bags or small plastic containers and fill with your favorites. Also consider a thermos, which can keep a snack of chili hot until the hunger pangs set in. And always hit the trail with a bag full of trail mix (pack up ziplock bags with walnuts, sunflower seeds, raisins, and dried apricots - a powerful combo of iron-rich foods that will nourish baby with a much-needed third trimester nutrient). 

 Make savvy substitutes: Whether you count on something sweet at 4:00 or salty at midnight (or both), fear not - there are many nutritious ways to satisfy those cravings. 

 For the midday slump, carrot or oat bran muffins can replace doughnuts and coffee cake; take them with a wedge of cheese or a container of yogurt, and you have made yourself a mini-meal. Or pick yourself up with apple wedges spread with peanut butter (if allergies are not a problem); all-fruit jam spread on a whole-wheat English muffin; cottage cheese with strawberries, tangerines, and cinnamon; yogurt topped with walnuts and dried fruit (yay iron!); or a smoothie. 

 And to manage the midnight munchies (if you can stay awake late enough to notice you have them), opt for air-popped popcorn sprinkled liberally with grated cheese (and spiced up with chili powder if you are a hot mama), crunchy soy chips, toasted pumpkin or sunflower seeds (salted and seasoned to taste), whole-wheat pretzels or baked potato chips dunked in hummus spread. If it is not Friday night without nachos, make yours the healthy way with baked tortilla chips, pre shredded low-fat cheese, black beans, and fresh chopped tomatoes (along with a few sliced jalapenos if you dare), and enjoy with a juice-and-sparkling water spritzer or virgin blender drink served in a frosty mug. Instead of diving into a half-gallon of ice cream with wild abandon and an extra large spoon, scoop out a serving of frozen yogurt, top it with toasted walnuts, some slightly warmed fruit-only preserves, and bananas - and split from the kitchen with a clear conscience. Need a dose of comfort? Warm up a can of tomato or vegetable soup, then top with a handful of grated cheese or a dollop of creamy cottage cheese. Is your dialing finger itching to call up for that greasy takeout pizza? Put it (and your other fingers) to work instead by compiling your own, healthier version in a snap: a whole-wheat English muffin slathered with tomato sauce, covered in shredded mozzarella, topped with a sliced tomato, and then sent to your toaster oven for a little broiling action.

Artificial Sweeteners And Pregnancy 


 Your morning coffee at home, the bowl of cereal, and then the decaf tea you grabbed at the cart at work - that is three packs of sugar times three, or nine teaspoons of sugar (144 calories) already. And it is only 9 a.m. At 31 weeks pregnant, there is nothing sweet about all those extra, empty calories sugar provides, as you are all too well aware (quickly calculating what you could have eaten instead). Yet all you can think of is what your mother told you about those rat studies on saccharin and the debates you have heard about aspartame during pregnancy. Were those just rat tales? What is the real scoop on artificial sweeteners and pregnancy? Here is the lowdown on the low-cal and no-cal sugar substitutes and their place (if any) when you are expecting: 

 Sucralose (Splenda): 
 It is sugar, sort of. At least it starts out life that way, before being chemically processed into a form that your body will not be able to absorb, making it sweet revenge (it is calorie-free). Sucralose, which has less of that aftertaste that gives sweeteners a bad name, appears to be safe during pregnancy and has been approved by the FDA for pregnant women to consume - so sweeten your day (and your coffee, tea, yogurt, and smoothies) with it if you want. It is also stable for cooking and baking (unlike aspartame), making that sugar-free chocolate cake less pipe dream, more possibility. Look before you leap to load up on foods that are sweetened with it though; they may contain other less innocuous chemicals - or just might not be over-all nutritious choices.

 Aspartame (Equal, NutraSweet): 
 Many experts think it is harmless, others think it is an unsafe artificial sweetener, pregnant or not. But this sweetener is FDA approved for pregnant women, though they do recommend you limit your consumption of aspartame during pregnancy. A packet or two of the blue stuff now and then, a can of diet Coke every once in a while - no problem. Just avoid consuming aspartame during pregnancy in large amounts (so yes, a small piece of sugarless gum is safe), and steer clear of it altogether if PKU is on your medical chart. 

 Saccharin (Sweet N Low): 
 The FDA has deemed saccharin safe, but there have been some questionable studies (though those rat studies you may have heard of never proved much - they were never replicated in humans). But other studies have suggested that saccharin gets to your baby through the placenta, and when it gets there, it is slow to leave. For that reason, you might want to stay away from the pink packets - or pick them up only occasionally (when there is no yellow in sight). 

 Acesulfame-K (Sunnette): 
 This substitute is also FDA-approved and has 200 times the sweetness of regular sugar. You will find it in baked goods, gelatin, gum, and soft drinks, but again - moderation is key. 

 Sorbitol: 
 Sorbitol is actually a nutritive sweetener, which is fine for women during pregnancy. But while it can not hurt your baby, it can have unpleasant gastro effects on you: In large doses, it can cause stomach upset and diarrhea, something no pregnant woman wants to have (diarrhea during pregnancy, besides being uncomfortable, can interfere with the absorption of vital nutrients, plus lead to dehydration). It is safe in moderate amounts but can lead to excess pregnancy weight gain if you overdo it. Sorbitol has more calories than other substitutes and less sweetness than regular sugar. 

 Mannitol: 
 Like sorbitol, it is a nutritive sweetener that is safe for pregnant women, and moderate amounts are fine, but its poor absorption by your body means it can cause unfortunate goings-on in your stomach. 

 Xylitol: 
 A sugar alcohol derived from plants (it is naturally occurring in many fruits and veggies), xylitol can be found in chewing gum, toothpaste, candies, and some foods. Considered safe during pregnancy in moderate amounts (so one pack of xylitol-sweetened gum a day is fine - but you might not want to chew through five), it has 40 percent fewer calories than sugar and has been shown to prevent tooth decay. 

 Stevia: 
 The latest sugar substitute to hit the market, this sweetener is derived from a South American shrub. Stevia has not been approved by the FDA as a sweetener (it is considered a dietary supplement), and no clear research proves it is safe during pregnancy. Your best bet is to check with your practitioner before using it. 

 Lactose: 
 Avoid this milk sugar if you are lactose intolerant, but otherwise, it is safe during pregnancy.

 Fruit-juice concentrates: 
 They are not exactly low-cal, but they are high in nutrients (from naturally occurring phytochemicals to added vitamin C and calcium). Since they are liquid, substituting them for granulated sugar in recipes takes a little know-how (you will need to choose recipes that call for a substantial amount of liquid, then sub the juice concentrate for that liquid, as well as for the sugar), but it is definitely do-able, and with delicious results. White grape juice concentrate, which has a sweeter, less fruity taste, will bake up to taste most like sugar. (See the Pregnancy Recipes list for dishes that use fruit-juice concentrates.) Or check out the health food section of your market (or your local health food market) for the many commercial products in which they are found, including cookies, cereals, granola bars, toaster pastries, yogurt, even soft drinks. Need another plus? Products that contain them are also more likely to contain healthier ingredients than sugar-loaded sweets.

Fever During Pregnancy 


 Feeling sick, and worried about your temperature creeping up? Here is what you need to know about fevers during pregnancy, including what is considered a fever in expectant women, what medicine you can take and the potential risks involved. 

 What temperature is considered a fever for a pregnant women? 
 If your temperature reaches 100 degrees F, call your practitioner immediately. Otherwise, a low-grade fever (one that is under 100 degrees F) usually is not something to worry about when you are expecting. That said, it is also something you should not ignore - so keep an eye on the thermometer to make sure the numbers do not start rising. 

 Can you get a fever in early pregnancy? 
 It is possible to get a fever any time throughout your pregnancy, and a high fever in the first weeks of pregnancy may be more risky than a flu later on. A study published in the journal Pediatrics linked fever, especially in the first trimester, to various birth defects - all the more reason to keep a very close eye on your temperature if you are feeling really under the weather. 

 What effects, if any, can a fever have on my pregnancy? 
 A mild fever under 100 degrees F is generally no cause for concern and typically will not have any effect on your pregnancy. But a higher fever can be more serious, which is why it is so important to give your practitioner a call as soon as you start to see those numbers go up. Pregnant women and their babies are more likely to suffer from serious complications from a high-grade fever, including birth defects like neural tube defects, congenital heart defects and oral clefts. There have also been a number of studies linking untreated high fevers in pregnant women with an increased risk of autism in babies, though experts say more research needs to be done and taking acetaminophen to bring the fever down seems to lower the risk. Catching the flu can lead to hospitalizations and preterm labor - all the more reason to get the flu shot if you are pregnant (or planning to get pregnant) around cold and flu season, ideally in October if possible. 

 What are the causes of fever during pregnancy? 
 You can get a fever during pregnancy for the same reasons you get a fever when you are not expecting. In fact, women are actually more likely to suffer from common viral infections like the flu or colds during pregnancy. That is because your immune system is suppressed in order to protect your fetus (which your body considers an outsider) from being rejected. Good news for your baby, not so good news for your sinuses. 
 Low-grade fevers may be the result of a benign viral infection like a cold, while higher fevers may be linked to the flu during pregnancy. Sometimes, a fever can be caused by a bacterial infection (like a urinary tract infection, kidney infection or strep throat, for example) that requires antibiotics. On that note, women are cautioned to avoid eating raw meat, fish and cheese during pregnancy to avoid exposure to listeria bacteria during pregnancy, which can also cause a high-grade fever. 

 What medications can I take for a fever when I am pregnant? 
 While you are waiting to speak to your doctor, take acetaminophen (Tylenol) to reduce a fever during pregnancy. Avoid aspirin or ibuprofen (Advil or Motrin) if you are expecting unless they are specifically recommended by your practitioner. 

 A few more tips to treat fever during pregnancy: 
 Take a tepid bath or shower 
 Drink plenty of water and other cold beverages to cool down and prevent dehydration 
 Keep clothing and covers light

Are You Drinking Enough Water During Pregnancy? 


 Is being pregnant driving you to drink? Well, it should - at least all the way to the water faucet. As a mom-to-be, it is essential to be doubly sure that you are drinking enough water. Here is what you need to know about drinking water during pregnancy, from the benefits (preventing hemorrhoids and other pregnancy symptoms), to how much you need (more than before), to how to ensure your water is safe (more important than ever). 

 Water delivers essentials to your fetus 
 Ever wonder how all the good stuff in the prenatal vitamins and healthy foods you are faithfully consuming every day are shipped to your fetus? It all starts with water, which helps your body absorb essential nutrients into the cells and transports vitamins, minerals and hormones to the blood cells. It is those nutrient-rich blood cells that reach the placenta and ultimately your baby - all with the help of H2O. 

 Your recommended daily water intake is higher during pregnancy 
 To that end, you will need more water to keep your system running for two during pregnancy. The Institute of Medicine says pregnant women in temperate climates should aim to drink 12 or 13 glasses (they count a glass as eight ounces) each day, which is slightly more than the amount for non-pregnant women (around 11 glasses each day). Try to space out your sips to keep them coming steadily throughout the day rather than gulping a lot at once, which could leave you feeling uncomfortably full. Since most of us do not drink enough fluids, filling a water bottle or two every morning and keeping it handy all day takes the hassle out of hydration. Be sure to sip before, during and after you work out, or if you find yourself outside on a hot day. Note, too, that if you feel thirsty, it is a sign that your body is already on its way to being dehydrated. 
 How can you tell if you are getting enough? If your trips to the bathroom are frequent and your urine is pale or colorless, you are drinking is on track. 

 Water can help prevent UTIs, constipation and hemorrhoids 

 Now that you are pregnant, you are not just eating and drinking for two - you are also excreting for two (ew, but true). That means you will have more trash to take out of your system than ever before. Enter water, which dissolves the waste products and helps flush them from the kidneys. Drinking enough water also keeps your urine diluted, which not only keeps things flowing but also keeps UTIs at bay (urine that hangs out too long in your bladder can become a breeding ground for infection-triggering bacteria), as well as bladder infections and kidney infections (which are types of UTIs). 
 A copious consumption of water also helps immeasurably in the poop department, helping to move solid wastes more speedily down the digestive path. And, since constipation is pretty common in pregnant women - not to mention the fact that constipation pressure can cause hemorrhoids - well bottoms up! (Could not help it!) 

 Water can help with fatigue, headaches, swelling and overheating 
 Is it crazy-hot in here - or are you pregnant? It is true, the heat is on (high!) when you are expecting. But if you drink water during pregnancy, you can keep the body cooling system running smoothly - even when your inner thermostat is cranked all the way up - by dispersing excess heat in the form of sweat. 
 An ample flow of fluids also keeps pregnancy fatigue in check - one of the first symptoms of dehydration is exhaustion - and can keep headaches at bay (another dehydration symptom). It also helps your body get rid of excess sodium among other things, minimizing swelling - particularly swollen feet or ankles (your doctor might call it (edema)). 

 Ensuring your water safe 
 It is never a bad idea to assess the cleanliness of your drinking water - and that is especially true when you are pregnant. While most of the water you drink likely comes from public water systems and is generally safe to drink, it can be contaminated with high levels of chemicals that could harm a fetus, including lead, mercury and arsenic. In addition, there is increasing evidence that BPA (an industrial chemical that mimics estrogen and is found in some plastics) can be problematic when you are expecting. Learn more on how to ensure your water supply is safe to drink when you are pregnant. 

 Water is not the only way to hydrate 
 Water is the best drink around, but if you are all watered out? There are plenty of other liquids that make the cut: Milk (an 8-ounce glass of skim yields just over seven ounces of water), sparkling or flavored waters, fruit and vegetable juices (watch out for added sugar in fruit juice and added sodium in veggie drinks) and decaffeinated teas are all great choices - just be sure you keep an eye on pasteurization, calorie info and all that. You should, however, limit your intake of soda (nothing but empty calories), as well as other beverages containing caffeine, since they have a diuretic effect (besides the other reasons to cut the caffeine during pregnancy). 

 Keep in mind, too, that about 20 percent of our daily water intake comes from food sources. Fruits pack the most water: One cup of watermelon or cantaloupe provides just under five ounces of water; a medium-size pear or one cup of strawberries provides about four and a half ounces; a medium size orange has four ounces. Got the sniffles? A cup of chicken soup yields roughly six ounces of water.

Calcium Supplements During Pregnancy 



 Whether you really can not tolerate the white stuff (because you are lactose intolerant), or just the thought of drinking it makes you sick, getting your daily dose of calcium can pose a challenge at 34 weeks pregnant when you do not (got milk.) Luckily, you can build your baby bones (and protect your own) with plenty of tasty milk alternatives: 


 If you are lactose intolerant. 

 If your body has trouble producing enough lactase - the enzyme that breaks down the lactose in milk - an encounter with dairy, especially in its most basic form (milk is as close to the cow as it comes) can lead to cramps, gas, bloating, and diarrhea. Try these tips to get the calcium you need without the stomach upset you definitely do not need: 
 Do not bring the lactose home. Shop smart and pick up lactose-free milk. You can even find it in a calcium-fortified form so you can get more bang for your milk buck. 
 Get your enzymes. Just because your body lacks lactase, does not mean you have to do without this milk-digesting enzyme. Lactase is available as capsules or chewable tablets - just take one whenever you eat or drink an offending dairy product. Or drop liquid lactase into milk or other dairy products to break down the lactose before it can bring on the bloat. 
 If you can not say milk (without getting cramps), just say cheese. Naturally aged hard cheeses like cheddar, Parmesan, and Swiss lose more than half of their lactose during processing. Try getting cheesy - you may be able to tolerate more than you think. 
 Get cultured. The good bacteria in yogurt (and in some frozen yogurt) work to break down lactose, so get active with those active yogurt cultures. 
 Get less milk. It is possible you can manage smaller amounts of dairy. Try drinking only a half cup of milk at a time or nibbling on a thin slice of cheese. And since lactose is easier to digest when mixed with other foods, particularly high fiber ones, take your milk with whole-grain cereal, or melt that cheese on a slice of whole-wheat bread. 
 Steer clear. If your symptoms are particularly bad, you may need to stay away from any food that contains dairy products. Look for products that say pareve or parve on the label, which indicates that it contains no dairy at all. And make sure you get your calcium from other nondairy sources (see below). 


 If you just can not stand milk. 

 If milk leaves a sour taste in your mouth, there are plenty of ways to sneak your calcium in: 
 Hide the milk. Blend it into a soothing smoothie. Pour it in creamy soups. Order it up in a nonfat decaf latte. 
 Explore the other side of dairy. You can bypass the milk case and still cash in on calcium. Most dairy products contain plenty - particularly yogurt (one cup has the same amount of calcium as a cup of milk) and cheese (one ounce, or a quarter-cup grated serves up a serving). 
 Do nondairy. No need to visit the dairy department to score your calcium fix. You will also find it in fortified fruit juice (orange, grapefruit, apple, cranberry, and others), calcium-enriched soy milk and cheese, as well as tofu, dark leafy greens, broccoli, and canned salmon mashed with the bones. 

 Keep in mind that skipping the milk means missing not only its calcium but also its buddy, vitamin D. Yogurt and cheese might be good sources of calcium, but they do not contain the big D. Luckily, getting your D is as easy as soaking up the sun for a few minutes a day (your body manufactures it in response to sunlight). Check, too, that the sunshine vitamin is in your prenatal tablet. (If you are drinking soy milk, look for a brand that is enriched with Vitamin D.) 

 If you are still worried about your calcium intake, talk to your practitioner, who may advise you to take a supplement (there are yummy kinds that now come in chocolate, strawberry, or orange and are chewy like caramels). If you have stomach trouble, whether it is due to dairy or not, remember that antacids like Tums or Rolaids often contain calcium.

Edema (Swelling of the Ankles and Feet) During Pregnancy 


 Your belly is not the only thing that is swelling these days – you may notice mild swelling throughout your body during pregnancy and, thanks to the laws of gravity, particularly in your feet and ankles. The amount of swelling you experience can vary by the hour (increasing in the evening) and by the weather (warmer temperatures forecast more swelling). 

 When Do Feet Swell During Pregnancy? 
 Edema affects about three quarters of pregnant women starting around week 22 to week 27 of pregnancy, and it will likely stick around until you give birth (on the bright side, pretty soon you will not be able to see anything below your belly anyway). 

 What Causes Swollen Ankles and Feet During Pregnancy? 
 During pregnancy, edema occurs when body fluids increase to nurture both you and your baby and accumulate in your tissues as a result of increased blood flow and pressure of your growing uterus on the pelvic veins and your vena cava (the large vein on the right side of your body that returns blood from your lower limbs to the heart). This causes you to experience this oh-so-necessary increase as oh-so-annoying swelling – particularly swollen ankles and feet (but also your hands, as you may have noticed when you last tried to take off your rings). You might also be sporting more swelling in your feet if your weight gain has been on the faster side. 

 Are There Risks Associated With Swollen Ankles and Feet? 
 Although it sure is not swell (especially when you try to squeeze into your shoes at the end of the day, when puffiness is at its peak), mild swelling of the ankles and feet caused by edema is harmless and perfectly normal. It is also just as normal not to experience noticeable swelling (one in four lucky pregnant women do not). However if your hands and/or face become puffy or if swelling persists for more than a day at a time (it does not improve overnight), call your practitioner. Excessive swelling can be one sign of preeclampsia – but when it is, it is accompanied by a variety of other symptoms (such as elevated blood pressure, rapid weight gain and protein in the urine). If your blood pressure and urine are normal (they are checked at each prenatal visit), there is nothing to be concerned about. 

 How to Stop Feet From Swelling While Pregnant: 

 Avoid long periods of standing or sitting. 
 If you are on your feet a lot, take breaks and have a seat. If you are sitting down a lot, take a five-minute stroll at least once an hour.
 Kick up your feet. 
 If possible, elevate your legs when you are sitting. Who has a better excuse to put up her feet than a pregnant woman? 
 Sleep on your side. 
 If you do not already, try sleeping on your side (preferably your left) – it helps keep your kidneys humming along, which in turn helps waste elimination and reduces swelling. 
 Move it. 
 Try to get some pregnancy-appropriate exercise, such as walking (which keeps the blood flowing instead of pooling) or swimming, if your practitioner OKs it (the water pressure pushes fluids from your tissues back into your veins, where it goes to your kidneys so you can pee it out). 
 Avoid tight elastic-top socks or stockings. 
 Your goal is to let blood and fluids flow as freely as possible. 
 Wear comfy shoes. Especially while you are out (those sexy slingbacks do not fit now, anyway). Consider orthotic shoes or inserts as well, which can make your feet feel better and can reduce leg and back pain during pregnancy too. Once you get home, switch to a pair of soft slippers. 
 Try support hose. 
 Opt for full pantyhose (with extra tummy room) or knee- or thigh-highs (a better choice if you are perpetually warm) that are not tight on top. Whichever type of support hose you choose, put them on in the morning before the daily swelling starts so they can do their job more effectively. 
 Drink lots of water . 
 It may seem counterintuitive to try to flush out fluids with fluids, but drinking eight to ten glasses of water a day will help rid your system of excess sodium and other waste products, minimizing swelling. 
 Do not go crazy with the salt shaker. 
 Limiting salt too much increases swelling – so do not cut it out entirely. But like everything, it is best to keep your intake in moderation and salt to taste.

 Another Reason for Tighter Shoes: Foot Growth 
 In addition to edema, there is another factor at play if your shoes are feeling a big snug: Like the rest of the ligaments in your body, the ones in your feet are loosening thanks to the hormone relaxin, allowing the bones to spread out. If you stick with your old shoes, your feet may feel pinched. After a few months the swelling will recede and the extra weight will fall away (usually). But although your joints and ligaments will tighten up, your feet may remain permanently larger - up to a full shoe size. Shoe shopping, anyone?

Heartburn During Pregnancy 


 Feeling the burn, baby? No one - not even a regular at the corner greasy spoon — does heartburn like a pregnant woman (except, of course, a pregnant woman who is a regular at the corner greasy spoon). You are likely feeling the unpleasant sensations you would expect if you had a flamethrower stationed in your chest or gut - including burning and discomfort from mouth to stomach to bowel. And you are not alone: Nearly half of expectant moms have also been feeling your pain - probably for most of their pregnancies. 

 What Causes Heartburn During Pregnancy? 
 Thanks to all the hormones circulating through your body during pregnancy, the muscle at the top of your stomach - the one that usually prevents digestive acids from splashing into the esophagus - relaxes (like all those other muscles in your digestive tract - and everywhere else in your body). This allows those painfully acidic digestive juices to splash back up, causing irritation and burning. What is more, you will feel a surge starting around week 30 to week 36, when your gigantic uterus (which has taken over your abdominal cavity) forces your stomach upwards toward your throat (at least that is the way it can feel). 

 What You Need to Know 
 The chances of having a completely heartburn-free pregnancy are slim to none. The good news is pregnancy-induced indigestion is also nothing to worry about – and it should disappear as soon as your baby appears on the scene. In the meantime, there are plenty of preventive measures and soothing strategies you can try. 

 Heartburn Prevention During Pregnancy 
 There are several ways to control and treat heartburn relief during pregnancy. And with so many options - and so much time – you will probably try them all: 
 Do not smoke. 
 It is yet another reason to quit today, if you have not already - and it is not even the best one. 
 Watch your weight. 
 Keep your pregnancy weight gain gradual and moderate to minimize the amount of pressure on your digestive tract. Extra pounds can make heartburn extra worse. Try to stay within the 25-to-35-pound recommended range. 
 Avoid heartburn-trigger foods . 
 Some foods are sure to light your heartburn fire. Just say no to highly seasoned spicy food, caffeine (this also relaxes the esophageal valve), alcohol (which is off the menu anyway), greasy foods of all kinds, and too much citrus. (If OJ gives you trouble, water it down a bit - or buy a low-acid variety.) Peppermint turns up the burn in some women, but not all. 
 Drink before and after meals. 
 And try not to drink while you are eating– or if you do, just drink a little. Too much fluid mixed with too much food will distend the stomach, aggravating heartburn. 
 Break it up. 
 Skip those big meals altogether - six small meals are the solution to just about whatever pregnancy symptoms are ailing you, from heartburn to bloating to lagging energy level. 
 Prop with pillows. 
 Even if you have put a few hours between your last mealtime and bedtime try sleeping with your head elevated about six inches. This helps to keep those gastric juices where they belong. 
 Think loose and flowing. 
 For heartburn relief during pregnancy, wear clothes that breathe. No matter how voluptuous your upper curves make you feel, if you have heartburn, now is not the time to wear anything that Pamela Anderson might favor - tight clothes just fuel the burn. 
 Catch the early bird special. 
 Not to save money - but to save yourself heartburn. Whether you are eating at home or out, take your last big meal at least two hours before bedtime so your stomach can get started on digestion before you lie down for the night. (A before-bed snack is fine, so long as it is light and easy to digest.) 
 Sit up and take notice. 
 Make sure to sit upright while eating - and stay that way for a couple of hours after you eat. Lying down, slouching, slumping, and stooping will do you in. And when you have to bend, do it with your knees instead of at your waist (or you will send all that acid for a repeat ride up your esophagus). 
 Chew it over. 
 Do your body a favor and eat slowly. Chewing is the first step in the digestive process, but the one that is most often neglected when eating is done on the run. The more you chew, the less work your stomach has to do. Plus when you eat too quickly, you often swallow air, which can form gas pockets in your belly.

 Heartburn Relief and Treatment 
 Pop a stick of sugarless gum after meals. It helps reduce excess acid (increased saliva can neutralize the acid in your esophagus). If you are concerned about artificial sweeteners and pregnancy, breathe easy - sugarless gum is fine in moderation. 
 Stay prepared. Keep a supply of Tums or Rolaids at popping distance (they will also give you a healthy dose of calcium while they ease the burn), but avoid medicines that contain sodium or sodium bicarbonate. 
 Block it. If your heartburn is persistent, you may want to talk to your doctor about over-the-counter heartburn medicines that control acid production, like proton-pump inhibitors (PPIs) or H2 blockers. They are generally considered safe during pregnancy – but as with any medication, you will want to get the OK and the recommended dosage first from your practitioner. 
 Feel like a natural woman. If you want to avoid over-the-counter remedies, you can try the following popular folk remedies for heartburn relief during pregnancy instead. 
 Papaya: Make sure the papaya is very ripe; unripe papaya may cause uterine contractions. Or ask your practitioner about the safety of using chewable papaya enzymes. (You can find these in health-food stores.) 
 Almonds: Good for calcium as well as being a stomach-settler. 
 A tablespoon of honey in warm milk: 
 Yummy and relaxing. Some say all dairy helps, and others say the opposite. (At the very least you will get in your calcium.) 

 If acid reflux occurs more than twice a week, or if you have not found relief after taking over-the-counter medications for more than two weeks, you may have a condition called gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) that requires specific lifestyle changes and medication – so be sure to talk to your doctor for diagnosis and treatment.

Benefits of Protein During Pregnancy 


 Protein is the cover girl of nutrients these days, getting raves from many successful dieters. Since you know weight-loss diets are downright dangerous for expectant moms and their babies, you need to appreciate protein during pregnancy on a deeper level - for the brain power behind the beauty. 

 Protein is made up of the amino acids that build your baby adorable face and every cell below it. At 37 weeks pregnant, your baby brain, in particular, needs these raw materials to transform itself into the wondrous organ that will help your baby breathe, walk, talk, and gleefully flush your car keys down the toilet in the years to come. 

 During pregnancy, you need three servings of protein every day (the equivalent of about 75 grams). Most people have no trouble reaching this goal (especially if they have spent any time on the low-carb bandwagon), although if you are having a vegetarian or vegan pregnancy you may have to work a little harder to find good sources of protein. 

 Getting your full protein quota is never more important than it is during this final trimester, when your baby brain is developing fast and furiously - but it is also a great time to up your intake of good protein sources that are extra high in omega-3 fatty acids, like DHA (another must-have nutrient when it comes to baby brains - plus, one that is known to lower your risk of postpartum depression). Get protein during pregnancy from all of these foods, but the starred ones are especially good sources of protein for their DHA star power: 
 Lean meat 
 Grass-fed lean meat 
 Poultry 
 Fish (fatty fish, like wild salmon, anchovies, and sardines contain the most brain-boosting fatty acids, but all fish have some. Learn how to safely eat fish during pregnancy.) 
 Eggs (choose DHA eggs for an omega-3 boost) 
 Milk and other dairy products 

 Vegan options include: 
 Beans 
 Tofu and other soy products (such as edamame and soy pasta) 
 TVP (texturized vegetable protein; check the label for the protein-to-calorie ratio to make sure you are getting the biggest bang for your nutritional buck) 
 Peanuts, peanut butter, other nuts and seeds (get the scoop on nuts during pregnancy) 
 Wheat germ 
 Whole-grain baked goods 
 Whole grains - an especially high-protein variety is quinoa (pronounced keen-wa) 
 Algae, like seaweed (an all-natural plant source of DHA) 

 It is also a good idea to chase protein during pregnancy with an adequate supply of pyridoxine. Never heard of it? It is the vitamin also known as B6, and its job is to help your body - and your baby - use all that protein to do its cell-building job. (Think of it this way: If protein is the brick, B6 is the mortar.) And B6 plays an especially big role in the development of the brain and nervous system. Like folic acid, it helps reduce the risk of neural tube defects. You will find B6 in prenatal vitamins and also in bananas, avocados, wheat germ, brown rice, bran, soybeans, oatmeal, potatoes, tomatoes, spinach, watermelon, and meat (see, there is overlap with your protein sources, making your job even easier).

Your Brain on Choline During Pregnancy 


 Can not remember where you left the car keys - or where you left the car? Showing up on Tuesday afternoon for a Monday morning meeting? Have your desk blanketed in Post-its reminding you to be home for that crib delivery - but managed to miss it anyway? Pregnancy forgetfulness has a way of sneaking up on you without any warning (or maybe you got a warning but you forgot). Here is a slightly unsettling, yet illuminating explanation why you have been having senior moments ever since you started gestating junior. 

 For sure, hormones play a part (the same ones that kick in when you are premenstrual - except they kick in at much higher levels, leaving you in a much thicker fog). But it also turns out - just as you suspected last time you spaced out when you were supposed to turn off the oven and ended up with burnt chicken instead of baked chicken - that your brain has actually been shrinking during pregnancy. Researchers have noted that the brain cell volume of pregnant women actually decreases during the third trimester of pregnancy, only to plump up a few months after delivery. So you are not imagining your brain drain at 38 weeks pregnant (and you have a valid medical excuse for why you forgot to pay the electric bill until the lights started flickering). But is there anything you can do to minimize the effects of your so-called placenta brain? 

 Luckily, there is - and it is to lean on choline. This essential nutrient helps improve brain function and is the building block for a memory-forming brain chemical called acetylcholine. What is more, choline plays a crucial role in the development of your baby brain - something occurring at a rapid clip now that you are in your third trimester. Researchers theorize that getting plenty of this brain boosting mineral during pregnancy can boost the cognitive function of both your baby - and you. (Another way to get through your day without leaving your credit card at a single cash register? Load up on those omega-3 like DHA-rich foods, the other best bud of your and your baby brain.) 

 Expectant moms are expected to get 450 mg of choline each day. You will probably get some from your prenatal vitamin (check the label), but it does not hurt to get some extra from your diet. You can easily get your share and more by eating such choline-rich foods as egg yolks (use DHA eggs to pack a memory-boosting omega-3 punch), beef, milk, soybeans (enjoy them in their crunchy roasted form or steamed in yummy green pods), citrus fruits, wheat germ, and nuts. 

 And do not stop once your baby born, especially if you are breastfeeding. Not only because you will need all the memory help you can get then (yes, your brain will be back to its pre pregnancy proportions - but you will still be in a fog thanks to sleep deprivation), but because nursing mothers need even more choline in their breastfeeding diet (remember, your baby brain is growing at a fast clip even after birth) - about 550 mg per day. So keep the choline coming, Mom!

Foods That Induce Labor 


 It is the expectant mom version of Fear Factor (minus the worm milkshake): By the time you are 39 weeks pregnant and within spitting distance of your due date, you are probably willing to do or eat anything to get to that million-dollar prize (your baby…not to mention a lap to hold baby on) more quickly. Unfortunately, at least as far as medical science is concerned (old wives are a different story), there is no miracle meal that will bring on labor. 

 Some women swear that castor oil works, but there is no proof that is true. Plus, the side effects of this gross tasting stuff are, well, pretty gross. Castor oil affects your bowels more than it affects your uterus (which could make the photos taken in the delivery room a bit…spotty). The same goes for herbal preparations, such as red raspberry leaf tea, which (minus the gut-wrenching consequences) is said to tone and relax the uterus. In both cases, there is no proof of either one safety or effectiveness. And many, many mothers who have been there, done that-will not ever again. (If you still want to try them, run the idea by your practitioner first for an okay.) 

 In the category of (can not hurt, might help) are foods such as eggplant, balsamic vinegar, and anything spicy. While there is no proof that any of these have labor-inducing qualities, plenty of moms swear they have gone straight from Joe House of Hot Wings to the labor and delivery floor. If your stomach can take the heat (late-pregnancy heartburn can be a killer!), there is no harm in indulging these old wives tales, as long as the so-called magic foods do not crowd out healthy choices in your diet. Other foods touted by old wives and others are any that get the bowels in an uproar (along the lines of castor oil, but in a kinder, gentler way), or at least get them moving. Or you could head over to the local Szechuan Palace and try a combo of the two categories: spicy and poop-inducing. General Tso chicken, anyone? And while you are at it, do not skip the pineapple for dessert. Some women claim that is what did it for them. 

 To date, there is no proof that these foods will start labor unless you have already begun to dilate. So you might just have to make the best of the waiting: Plan a night out. Wear a lovely outfit (it will be a long time before you get to wear a dry-clean-only dress again) and go to a super-fancy restaurant with your partner and maybe a few pals to enjoy one of your last nights out without a sitter. Make sure to order your favorite appetizer and main course - with an eye on the dessert cart to come. Sit down, relax, and get ready to take your first bite - if anything will bring on your water breaking, that will! 

 To date, there is no proof that these foods will start labor unless you have already begun to dilate. So you might just have to make the best of the waiting: Plan a night out. Wear a lovely outfit (it will be a long time before you get to wear a dry-clean-only dress again) and go to a super-fancy restaurant with your partner and maybe a few pals to enjoy one of your last nights out without a sitter. Make sure to order your favorite appetizer and main course - with an eye on the dessert cart to come. Sit down, relax, and get ready to take your first bit . if anything will bring on your water breaking, that will!

Losing the Pregnancy Weight 


 By now, chances are you are pretty much used to riding the weight gain elevator. (Going up? And up? And up?) So used to it, that you probably do not even blink - or recoil in horror - as your practitioner scale tallies up your most recent gain (and the nurse announces it loudly to anyone passing through the hallway before recording it in your chart). 

 Which may make this week weigh-in a little surprising, and perhaps a little unsettling - particularly if you are not prepared for it. Because if you are like most women who have reached the end of pregnancy, you have also reached the end of pregnancy weight gain. Instead of (going up) as per usual, the numbers on the scale at 40 weeks pregnant may not be going anywhere - or may even be (going down,) tracking a weight loss during this pregnancy home stretch. 

 You may be at a loss to explain your loss (or lack of gain) by looking in the mirror (that is, if you are still looking in those). After all, your legs and ankles are still plenty puffy, your belly is the size of a prize-winning watermelon, and there is no way you can squeeze into your old shoes, never mind your wedding band. 

 So what triggers this typical late pregnancy trend? Baby certainly not to blame (and, do not worry - has not gotten those tiny hands on a copy of South Beach yet). In fact, he or she is likely packing on pounds even if you are not (and even if you are dropping them). 

 This normal weight-gain slow down or standstill is actually one way that your body gets ready for labor - a sign that all systems are gearing up for the big event (and for the much bigger weight loss of childbirth). Here is what may account for this late pregnancy (down scale): 
 Toward the end of pregnancy, the level of amniotic fluid starts to decrease - even before your water officially (breaks.) Less amniotic fluid means less water weight, literally. 
 The increased urge that you are feeling (all the time) to urinate now that your baby head is pressing down on your bladder means that you are flushing out fluids faster than ever before. Less water in your body - less weight in your body.
